While this patch solves the main use-case, there are two issues remaining.

1. If root_gb = 0, the user can still bypass flavor restrictions.
2. It doesn't take ephemeral_gb into account."}, {'account_id': 6896, 'date': '2013-05-10 04:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

I take back my second issue stated above. I guess we should focus on root_gb first.'}, {'account_id': 6896, 'date': '2013-05-10 04:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If root_gb = 0, the user can still bypass flavor restrictions"}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-05-10 15:50:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I completely disagree with the points above regarding root_gb and ephemeral_gb.

Admins can also set root_gb to be well beyond the capabilities of an individual node or the storage subsystem.  Setting it to 0 just means let the image do whatever it wants.  Ultimately, this is an admin-set configuration choice, users cannot manipulate flavors.  The same applies for ephemeral_gb.

The premise of the bug was that a user could abuse image upload capabilities to consume all the storage.  If an admin, through flavor choices, is allowing that to happen, then it's a config issue and not something we should be addressing in this bug."}, {'account_id': 6896, 'date': '2013-05-10 16:12:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Rafi, I see what you mean. It's an admin controlled variable. Thanks for pointing it out."}, {'account_id': 3189, 'date': '2013-05-10 16:13:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This has come up a few times in comments already on previous patch sets so I will address it in a review message so folks don't have to look at past patch sets.

Having a flavor that sets the root size to 0 and having nova effectively ignore that size and use the size of the image is considered a feature at this time, not a bug. Its beyond the scope of this bug to change or deprecate that feature.

The fix proposed addresses the issue described in a way that is compatible the existing features of nova and the data provided by glance.

If we want to consider changing the feature that should be opened as a separate bug or better yet a blueprint."}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-05-10 18:11:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

No problem with the zero-size-means-ignore behavior if that's what we want.  But there should be a comment in the code, so that anyone reading it knows it's intentional and not a bug.  Should save some pain in future reviews."}, {'account_id': 3189, 'date': '2013-05-10 18:47:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:35:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-09 20:38:16.000000000', 'message': "Check QCOW2 image size during root disk creation

glance can only tell us the size of the file, not the virtual
size of the QCOW2. As such we need to check the virtual size of
the image once its cached and ensure its <= to the flavor's
root disk size.

Change-Id: I833467284126557eb598b8350a84e10c06292fa9

commit_message:
Check QCOW2 image size during root disk creation

glance can only tell us the size of the file, not the virtual
size of the QCOW2. As such we need to check the virtual size of
the image once its cached and ensure it's <= to the flavor's
root disk size.

Change-Id: I833467284126557eb598b8350a84e10c06292fa9
Fixes: bug 1177830

commit_message:
Renames infrastructure files for CI

From bug report:

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: I6befe86855938368281bf2af40989dbe27141496
Fixes: Bug #1179008

And I doubt the actual usefulness of 'topic', at least in Cinder scope, everything is of the same topic 'volume' by default and I guess nobody would change that but I could be wrong."}, {'account_id': 5538, 'date': '2013-05-23 07:40:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

If and when the file shares service gets into Cinder, there will be 'share' topic too.. But I dont think currently the topic is something other than 'volume'"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-05-23 19:26:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Well, part of the reason I wrote this was because all I saw was "service is down or disabled" and didn't really know what it was talking about... it's not a terribly helpful message.  Should I just change the message to say "volume service is down: host %s" or so?'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-05-23 20:27:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-05-24 14:07:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-05-24 14:08:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 04:45:19.000000000', 'message': "get_instance_security_groups() fails if no name on security group

The following patch fixes a bug in get_instance_security_groups() where
it tries to access security_groups['id'] but security_groups is a string.
This patch also removes some stubs that were not needed in a few unit test.

Fixes bug 1182738

Change-Id: Ia64db2e40d4a0e163344b4234112dbde71b1e132
"}]
commit_message:
get_instance_security_groups() fails if no name on security group

The following patch fixes a bug in get_instance_security_groups() where
it tries to access security_groups['id'] but security_groups is a string.
This patch also removes some stubs that were not needed in a few unit test.

Fixes bug 1182738

Change-Id: Ia64db2e40d4a0e163344b4234112dbde71b1e132

Change-Id: I547a94e2db0dd967852b3cb8532dd0adb11e693b
"}]
commit_message:
removes project_id/tenant_id from v3 api urls

Adds a new APIMapper for V3 that doesn't prefix every
url with the project_id/tenant_id.

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-remove-project-id.

Change-Id: I547a94e2db0dd967852b3cb8532dd0adb11e693b

commit_message:
Configure logging format flexibly

Now we can get tempest log file with options in run_tests.sh.
This adds log.py and enables to configure log format more flexibly
using configuration file.
This adds a LoggerAdaptor and a Formatter to output each test name
to log lines.

Implements: blueprint add-logging-configuration

Change-Id: I88cf18bb8bbc152e62ac83a9c7dc26067b7a11bd

commit_message:
Ensure API extensions for NVP are loaded by default

commit_message:
Removed superflous eval usage.

It was being used as a hex string parser, which is not necessary given
that the int builtin can do this.

Change-Id: I710093fc83c175ac08d827bb93ba878703ee817a

commit_message:
Install dkms before using it.

Updates the new 99-dkms element so that it installs the package
before using it.

Fixes LP Bug #1183785.

Change-Id: Ia191ed3cae707a8c8591f849dc0c6293e849d64a

[{'created': '2013-05-24 08:36:48.000000000', 'message': 'Detach Volumes from an Instance in parallel

Use a PollingTaskGroup to ensure that if there are multiple Volumes
attached to an Instance they are detached in parallel rather than serially.

Change-Id: Ice399ae495af75558f2f8b1b1dc330d0b556a269
'}]
commit_message:
Detach Volumes from an Instance in parallel

Use a PollingTaskGroup to ensure that if there are multiple Volumes
attached to an Instance they are detached in parallel rather than serially.

Change-Id: Ice399ae495af75558f2f8b1b1dc330d0b556a269

[{'created': '2013-05-24 08:36:47.000000000', 'message': "Handle instance volume attachments with co-routines

Don't sit in a loop when attaching volumes to instances, use a task that
yields control and allows them to run in parallel - and, in future, in
parallel with other resources being created.

Change-Id: I4653baa87b09a9fb6c2c16b51218f4ea2f2ae6dd
"}]
commit_message:
Handle instance volume attachments with co-routines

Don't sit in a loop when attaching volumes to instances, use a task that
yields control and allows them to run in parallel - and, in future, in
parallel with other resources being created.

Change-Id: I4653baa87b09a9fb6c2c16b51218f4ea2f2ae6dd

[{'created': '2013-05-26 16:31:51.000000000', 'message': "Added '%' before snapshot variable

In function create_snapshot for cinder volume, '%' was missed
before variable snapshot from message defination. It was causing
an error during translation of debug message. Included '%'
for getting proper debug log.

Fixes: bug #1183736
Change-Id: I894639a4e5a69be80f4f53ec9d4f9f8648870173
"}]
commit_message:
Added '%' before snapshot variable

In function create_snapshot for cinder volume, '%' was missed
before variable snapshot from message defination. It was causing
an error during translation of debug message. Included '%'
for getting proper debug log.

Fixes: bug #1183736
Change-Id: I894639a4e5a69be80f4f53ec9d4f9f8648870173

commit_message:
Switch to Semantic Versioning

Configure the block-storage coobook with the new versioning scheme
we discusssed on the ML. It will start out at 7.0.0(7th OpenStack
release).

Change-Id: I612ac4e6b9613b2952ed35f636c4bad689e5338a
Fixes: Bug 1184210

[{'created': '2013-05-19 19:58:06.000000000', 'message': 'Update test_networks.py to v2 of Quantum API

Fixes bugs in the test suite tempest.tests.network.test_networks that prevents
Jenkins gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full to execute succesfully. The
problem was that the test suite was using v1 of the Quantum API, which
according to the "Quantum API Guide (V2.0)" has been removed from the code
base. Please see note at bottom of:

docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-network/2.0/content/Overview-d1e71.html

The test suite was patched to use operations supported by v2 of the Quantum
API. This required patches in the following files:

1) tempest.common.rest_client was patched to provide the correct end-point for
v2 of the Quantum API

2) tempest.services.network.json.network_client was patched to support create,
delete, list and show operations for the 3 basic abstractions offered by the
Quantum API: networks, sub-networks and ports

3) tempest.tests.network.base was patched to create a network and a subnetwork
using v2 Quantum API operations.

4) tempest.tests.network.test_networks was patched to invoke v2 Quantum API
operations. Individual tests invoking obsolete operations were eliminated

Fixes bug 1131458
Fixes bug 1159229

Change-Id: I320c46f2a42d8fd9dbfd496e8f357e21eb1c9259
(cherry picked from commit cc939612b3aaff0acbe51e2175cd39b9c080f858)
'}]
commit_message:
Update test_networks.py to v2 of Quantum API

Fixes bugs in the test suite tempest.tests.network.test_networks that prevents
Jenkins gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full to execute succesfully. The
problem was that the test suite was using v1 of the Quantum API, which
according to the "Quantum API Guide (V2.0)" has been removed from the code
base. Please see note at bottom of:

docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-network/2.0/content/Overview-d1e71.html

The test suite was patched to use operations supported by v2 of the Quantum
API. This required patches in the following files:

1) tempest.common.rest_client was patched to provide the correct end-point for
v2 of the Quantum API

2) tempest.services.network.json.network_client was patched to support create,
delete, list and show operations for the 3 basic abstractions offered by the
Quantum API: networks, sub-networks and ports

3) tempest.tests.network.base was patched to create a network and a subnetwork
using v2 Quantum API operations.

4) tempest.tests.network.test_networks was patched to invoke v2 Quantum API
operations. Individual tests invoking obsolete operations were eliminated

Fixes bug 1131458
Fixes bug 1159229

Change-Id: I320c46f2a42d8fd9dbfd496e8f357e21eb1c9259
(cherry picked from commit cc939612b3aaff0acbe51e2175cd39b9c080f858)

[{'created': '2013-05-24 16:04:27.000000000', 'message': 'Don't throw ValueError for invalid volume id

If a user runs something like "cinder-manage volume delete a1234",
a ValueError is thrown because it fails to cast to int.
Catch this and treat the parameter as an id which will result in a
later VolumeNotFound error rather than breaking this way.

Change-Id: I95a9b9d7628cebe4b6d855ea925b0ad3a5f1c4c4
'}]
commit_message:
Don't throw ValueError for invalid volume id

If a user runs something like "cinder-manage volume delete a1234",
a ValueError is thrown because it fails to cast to int.
Catch this and treat the parameter as an id which will result in a
later VolumeNotFound error rather than breaking this way.

Change-Id: I95a9b9d7628cebe4b6d855ea925b0ad3a5f1c4c4

commit_message:
Added conversion specifier for proper log

In function create_for_sg_rule conversion specifier after string varaible
"rule_id" was missed. It was causing an error during translation of debug
message due to unavailability of conversion specifier. Included proper
conversion specifier for getting proper debug log.

Fixes: bug #1183734

Change-Id: I0342a091fb8199273c1bb9af59c42c0e09c39349

commit_message:
Nicira plugin: List ports on network gateways

Bug 1183277

This patch adds a read-only attribute to the network gateway API
extension. This attribute will return the list of ports connected to
a gateway, including their segmentation types and ids.
This patch now adds joined load for a gateway's connections, thus
avoiding extra queries to the db.

Change-Id: I2b22c94eed5bc02be16771660008d31c74a8628e

commit_message:
Perform a sync with oslo-incubator.

This oslo-incubator sync pulls in a new log.py which will make quantum's
default log output format the same as nova, glance and cinder (once
cinder's corresponding oslo sync merges). This common log format
simplifies log indexing as part of CI and makes lives easier for
deployers.

This sync does add a requirement on six as jsonutils depends on it. It
updates install_venv_common.py to be python26 compatible. It also brings
in a bunch of recent python3 compatibility that was added to oslo.

Fixes bug 1183144

Change-Id: Id0f196d7b5680e5950e4a27d66042bf00ccd49e6

commit_message:
Fix resize when instance has no image

This patch makes it possible to resize an instance that has no image
supplied (was booted from volume), by avoiding calling the image service
and thus causing an uncaught exception, if there was no image suplied in
the first place.

Fixes bug: 1182114
blueprint: improve-boot-from-volume

Change-Id: I67d63a7aef699b555897582c74b04e857db7aafb
(cherry picked from commit 4465b705fc7cb7a150a7f8d6f70ccf6c20ff3284)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-02 19:11:54.000000000', 'message': "Fix building quantumapi network model with network list

Bug 1171636 occurs when _build_network_info_model() receives a list
of networks that does not fully map all of an instance's ports.
It crashes in _ensure_requested_network_ordering() when the list of
all ports is sorted by the subset of networks provided.

This change simplifies the early part of that function to only
consider ports within the networks provided, and to always sort those
ports in network order. This allows us to remove some error path
code from the loop below that iterates over the ports (which contained
a fatal typo, by the way) which is now dead code.

The affected code is really untested at the moment, due to the
structure of the method, making it hard to add a unit test to cover
this fix. In order to make the change clear from the existing code,
this fix is provided here first, and the following patch restructures
the method and add tests for this change and the rest of the surrounding
code.

Fixes bug 1171636

Change-Id: Idf519a88415844451b18959b38cc48ce92c090d1
(cherry picked from commit 08c7cf5c67a75dea9b453bd915a0cd55e67c4adc)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix building quantumapi network model with network list

Bug 1171636 occurs when _build_network_info_model() receives a list
of networks that does not fully map all of an instance's ports.
It crashes in _ensure_requested_network_ordering() when the list of
all ports is sorted by the subset of networks provided.

This change simplifies the early part of that function to only
consider ports within the networks provided, and to always sort those
ports in network order. This allows us to remove some error path
code from the loop below that iterates over the ports (which contained
a fatal typo, by the way) which is now dead code.

The affected code is really untested at the moment, due to the
structure of the method, making it hard to add a unit test to cover
this fix. In order to make the change clear from the existing code,
this fix is provided here first, and the following patch restructures
the method and add tests for this change and the rest of the surrounding
code.

Fixes bug 1171636

Change-Id: Idf519a88415844451b18959b38cc48ce92c090d1
(cherry picked from commit 08c7cf5c67a75dea9b453bd915a0cd55e67c4adc)

commit_message:
Use an SSH pool to manage SSH connection

Use an SSH pool to hold all SSH clients,this makes driver work when
mutiple requests received in short time.Rewrite method create() and
do not set socket timeout to be None because "None" leads to closing
ssh client blocking.

This patch alse fix:
make "Not format" to be "Notformat" in function _find_lun.
Change the type of "free_capacity_gb" fron string to be float.Because
type string will lead to cinder scheduler filter failure.

Fixes bug: 1162251
Change-Id: I7d2270bb23ccfec27e618a686ab8c278a72f2244

commit_message:
Prevent '500' error when using forbidden marker

If an existing image id was used as a marker, but
the user didn't have access to that image a '500'
error occurred. Return '400' instead.

Fixes bug 1178307.

Change-Id: Ib632297d944a19e18694fff154307a3bc6d5b625

commit_message:
RBD store uses common utils for reading file chunks

Prevents cases where the image_size passed to the RBD store is larger
than the actual image_file which attempts to write 0 bytes of data
causing image.write to hang indefinitely.

Fixes LP Bug #1146830

Change-Id: I56216437a212c0c802d2ed349d88b3bd0d3bb4d7

(1 inline comment)

Nice work, I like all the extra tests, but there is one little whitespace nit.

Also, this is a pretty big change, I think you need to do 2 things: 

First I would probably split up this change. You've got some little refactors and changes to existing tests in this commit. (For example changing the exception code to the the equivalent int) I think that it would be better to split out those changes. So just make this commit solely the new tests and add a commit on top for the changes to the existing tests.

Secondly I think you should add some more detail to the commit message. It doesn't really explain any details about how you're improving the glance api unit tests or what tests you're adding (or any mention the refactors and fixes for existing tests...)

I've found this wiki page to be helpful when formatting commit messages and figuring out how to split up large changes:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 6719, 'date': '2013-03-14 11:34:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-03-14 11:34:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Improve unit tests for glance.api.v1 module

Add test for glance.api.v1:
* tests for glance.api.v1.filters.validator
* tests for glance api add member method
* tests for glance api replace member method
* tests for glance api delete member method
* tests for registry api image details method
* tests for registry api image delete method
* tests for registry api add/delete/update/get member methods

Fixes: bug #1152230
Change-Id: I79d06b2281ba0c9b8d10b9300fffe6cc3c69c4ee

commit_message:
rbd: remove extra str() conversions and test with unicode

librbd doesn't handle unicode, so strings passed to it must be plain
ascii. Originally the rbd store did this before each call, but since
3aea9320d20d0291c5b4b027a585370d8e658a95 it only needed to convert to
ascii in StoreLocation and add(). Remove the extraneous calls to
str(), and add a test that uses a unicode image_id and uri to make
sure unicode isn't passed to librbd anywhere.

Change-Id: Ib7656126e044775f516fa6665e28f6d474820665
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

commit_message:
rbd: return image size when asked

Implement get_size(), and use it for the second part of the return
value of get().

Convert the old-style functional tests into tests using the store test
base class. These test the store api directly, and are more up to date
than the old functional tests that went through the api. The store tests
base class already includes tests for get() and get_size().

Fixes bug 1180565

Change-Id: I85ca0a0ab3155d1a25607ba9dc210be5719bf85c
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

commit_message:
Respond with 412 after upload if image was deleted.

When updating the image after upload, we should return an
HTTPPreconditionFailed instead of a 500 error if the image cannot
be found.

This will also provide more information to nova when this occurs
during snapshotting.

Fixes bug 1176174

Change-Id: I270ee129470323dae3919ed0a8c335eae7c24061

So, I want to see the first patch get in first, before this one goes in.

This is lower priority, because I think you can use a separate server (not involving XenServer) to run the DHCP agent.

But this is very useful for developers doing a deployment using devstack or similar, so once Mate gives it the thumbs up, I would love to see this go upstream."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Restored'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

The latest patch fixes the pep8 failure.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Why exactly is a different solution required - were you unable to test the patch successfully or is there another deficiency you have identified?  Consider reaching out to me on the mailing list or irc to discuss this issue further.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 2649, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (5 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Having one agent controlling multiple switches just does not look good. I think, to support the mentioned configuration, we would need to:
- Create a XenServer network, with nothing attached to it (not even the OS VM), let it be controlled/used by OpenStack, as a pure - VM switch, let's call it DOM0_VM_BRIDGE
- Create another XenServer network, which will be connected to OpenStack VM's "VM network" interface, call it DOM0_VM_INT
- Create an additional bridge inside OpenStack VM, connected to eth1, call it DOMU_VM_INT
- Start two agents in OpenStack VM, one controlling DOM0_VM_BRIDGE, having a bridge mapping to DOM0_VM_INT, the other agent would manipulate domU's integration bridge, having a mapping to push the bytes through DOMU_VM_INT

I am going to set that up tomorrow. Any suggestions?'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I am looking at this change at the moment. With these changes, I got it working:

https://github.com/citrix-openstack/quantum/commit/b267632284ebb5f3f66137e85881d976f5d145c7

expect amended patch soon.

also related (testing efforts):
https://github.com/citrix-openstack/qa/blob/master/xenserver-quantum-devstack.sh'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Abandoned

Abandoning this change in preference to Mate's proposal to run separate l2 agents for managing the integration bridges in dom0 and domU."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-26 07:15:17.000000000', 'message': "Add support for DHCP agent in XS/XCP compute domU.

 * Config doc: http://wiki.openstack.org/QuantumDevstackOvsXcp

 * For a single-node devstack configuration, the DHCP agent will
   to run in the compute domU, which means DHCP servers need to attach to
   ports on an integration bridge in domU.  For DHCP service to be
   available to VM's, the dom0 and domU integration bridges need to be
   joined via a common interface and traffic between the two bridges
   trunked, and DHCP ports on the domU bridge need to be tagged with the
   appropriate local vlan.
 * Two changes are implied by this use-case:
   1. The OVS agent, which is responsible for tagging ports with the
      local vlan associated with the port's network, needs to tag ports
      on both the dom0 and domU integration bridges.  Since the agent
      keeps local vlan state in memory, running more than one agent
      would require a state-sharing mechanism, so this implementation
      chose the simpler path of relying on a single agent to interact
      with both the dom0 and domU bridges.  The major change was
      updating port-handling methods to be passed the bridge associated
      with a port, rather than presuming a default bridge.
   2. The OVS agent needs to ignore the interface between the dom0 and
      domU bridges.  The interface is not known to Quantum and the agent
      would put the associated port on the 'dead vlan', effectively
      cutting off communication between the bridges.  This
      implementation changes the agent to ignore ports on the dom0
      bridge that have mac addresses used by interfaces in domU.
 * Supports blueprint xenapi-ovs

Change-Id: Id707eaba60c2ed2e9d72eb6791a8a6aa8378c9b8

commit_message:
Add support for DHCP agent in XS/XCP compute domU.

 * Config doc: http://wiki.openstack.org/QuantumDevstackOvsXcp

 * For a single-node devstack configuration, the DHCP agent will
   to run in the compute domU, which means DHCP servers need to attach to
   ports on an integration bridge in domU.  For DHCP service to be
   available to VM's, the dom0 and domU integration bridges need to be
   joined via a common interface and traffic between the two bridges
   trunked, and DHCP ports on the domU bridge need to be tagged with the
   appropriate local vlan.
 * Two changes are implied by this use-case:
   1. The OVS agent, which is responsible for tagging ports with the
      local vlan associated with the port's network, needs to tag ports
      on both the dom0 and domU integration bridges.  Since the agent
      keeps local vlan state in memory, running more than one agent
      would require a state-sharing mechanism, so this implementation
      chose the simpler path of relying on a single agent to interact
      with both the dom0 and domU bridges.  The major change was
      updating port-handling methods to be passed the bridge associated
      with a port, rather than presuming a default bridge.
   2. The OVS agent needs to ignore the interface between the dom0 and
      domU bridges.  The interface is not known to Quantum and the agent
      would put the associated port on the 'dead vlan', effectively
      cutting off communication between the bridges.  This
      implementation changes the agent to ignore ports on the dom0
      bridge that have mac addresses used by interfaces in domU.
 * Supports blueprint xenapi-ovs

Change-Id: Id707eaba60c2ed2e9d72eb6791a8a6aa8378c9b8

commit_message:
Simplify help string for --config-file

As Doug pointed out, we can simplify including the defaults for
--config-file in its help string by using argparse's builtin %(default)s
substitution.

Change-Id: I818101a222a64c12617c89d1f498a0a7c50b2184

commit_message:
Switch to Semantic Versioning

Configure the dashboard coobook with the new versioning scheme we
discusssed on the ML. It will start out at 7.0.0(7th OpenStack
release).

Change-Id: I217d16645f7a86c184ced1e383b37eb101376c47
Fixes: Bug 1184212

commit_message:
Moved swift container cleanup to a class method.

The same piece of code was used in almost every tearDownClass method, moved it
into a separate method to remove code redundancy.

Change-Id: I173af3f46fc2f6771237ab29b472249b00a9ed2d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 19:01:45.000000000', 'message': "Limit tests should pass correct image and flavor

The existing absolute limit tests were passing hard-coded values for
`flavor_ref` and `image_ref`. This patch switches it to use the values defined
in the tempest config.

Since these hard-coded values were incorrect, it imposed an order on which the
validation checks in Nova had to be run, which is not something we want.

By passing correct data, we're only testing that the limit test was performed,
not that it was performed before the image-check, for example.

Change-Id: I93e29c3be0f257de65a8e87b3552616786e205db
"}]
commit_message:
Limit tests should pass correct image and flavor

The existing absolute limit tests were passing hard-coded values for
`flavor_ref` and `image_ref`. This patch switches it to use the values defined
in the tempest config.

Since these hard-coded values were incorrect, it imposed an order on which the
validation checks in Nova had to be run, which is not something we want.

By passing correct data, we're only testing that the limit test was performed,
not that it was performed before the image-check, for example.

Change-Id: I93e29c3be0f257de65a8e87b3552616786e205db

'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-05-21 14:12:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I don't see hints implemented in the Cinder scheduler...what did I miss?"}, {'account_id': 1531, 'date': '2013-05-21 19:40:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Avishay The scheduler hints is a mechanism to allow users to pass some special parameters into filters or weighers on scheduling stage, which use them for their own purposes. So, implementation of scheduler hints affects various layers of the cinder. At first, a message body received from client and parsed into cinder-api can contains the special item named scheduler_hints (look at cinder/api/v2/volumes.py in this patch). At second, this parameter is passed into filter_properties (look at cinder/volume/api.py in this patch). Properties are used into filters and weighers and may affect the choice of a host.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-05-22 05:01:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Hi Nikolai, all in all I think this is great, the only issue I had was carrying forward the legacy format that Nova is supporting (as noted by Avishay).  We don't need to carry that baggage so might as well take it out IMO.

I had another comment that's more of an observation and I don't expect you to address it in your code here."}, {'account_id': 5538, 'date': '2013-05-22 07:16:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Avishay:

"Cinder already have filter scheduler and filter as well to support scheduler hints"
Rephrasing it, I understood it as: "Cinder has filter scheduler with filters, so that we can use the filters to support scheduler hints."

I hope I caught the correct line which might have confused you.'}, {'account_id': 7535, 'date': '2013-05-22 09:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7535, 'date': '2013-05-22 09:26:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 10:17:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Implement scheduler hints for API v2

We've done this implementation because we need to use scheduler hint in
cinder with some specific filters. So, most part of code have been
imported from nova.

bp scheduler-hints
docimpact

Change-Id: I4c8a78ade4ff668d79e7aa6d0d358029754e3d90

approach.

Change-Id: Ibb9fc84f7b46d848b0c1ac761a3be952c99f7509
'}, {'created': '2013-05-24 20:25:50.000000000', 'message': "Update IPMI driver to work with resource manager.

single instance of it, and pass (task, node) to IPMI methods.  This
brings the IPMI class in line with the base ControlDriver class
definition.

commit_message:
Update IPMI driver to work with resource manager.

Update the IPMI driver so that Ironic's resource manager can maintain a
single instance of it, and pass (task, node) to IPMI methods.  This
brings the IPMI class in line with the base ControlDriver class
definition.

Add a missing exception to common/exceptions.py.

IPMI driver methods presently support being called for a single node at
a time.  Support for multiple nodes passed down by the TaskManager is
not part of this patch.

Remove terminal support. To be added back later.

Change-Id: Ibb9fc84f7b46d848b0c1ac761a3be952c99f7509

commit_message:
Update [reserve|release]_nodes to accept a tag.

Update the reserve_nodes and release_nodes DB methods to accept an
arbitrary "tag", instead of accessing the global CONF.host setting.

Add unit tests to validate behaviour of both single- and multiple-node
reservations.

Change-Id: Idf5fce13a6aee3dd9c234bf7f18f17d8811383af

commit_message:
Changed _get_git_directory() to use git itself.

This lets pbr work on projects that are checked out as submodules.

Change-Id: I8c47a7dbae0bd390bd2529f972ffe9920aed374e
Reviewed-on: https://review.openstack.org/29619
Reviewed-by: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Reviewed-by: Clark Boylan <clark.boylan@gmail.com>
Approved: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Tested-by: Jenkins

commit_message:
Use six for iteritems(), itervalues(), and next()

From http://docs.python.org/3.1/whatsnew/3.0.html:

- dict.iteritems and dict.itervalues is no longer supported
- A new builtin next() was added to call the __next__() method
  on an object.

Use six to make the right choice for us for better python3
compat.

Change-Id: Ibdc0033894ac3a1db2222238ca9b6395f4b3cfdb
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

quantum accordingly.

subject: Fix race in reraising exceptions.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-18 01:39:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The problem with re-raising in this manner is that you're creating a new exception, losing the original one and associated traceback.

To preserve the traceback you can:  exc_info = sys.exc_info()  before the log and then raise exc_info[0], exc_info[1], exc_info[2] afterwards.

In oslo-incubator, you can find a context manager that does this for you in the excutils module."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-18 01:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(Side note: next eventlet version will be fixed to not eat the exception, also)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-18 01:52:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-18 01:01:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix race in reraising exceptions.

If you're using eventlet and have code like this:

    except SomeException as err:
        log_this_error(err)
        raise

then you're vulnerable to a race condition that could cause the
reraise to fail. What happens is that log_this_error() does some
socket IO (e.g. to syslog), and that IO gives eventlet an opportunity
to trampoline to a different greenthread, and by the time your
greenthread resumes, the current exception has been cleared, so the
bare "raise" statement causes its own exception.

The fix is simple: don't use the implicit current exception.

    except SomeException as err:
        log_this_error(err)
        raise err   # <--- now the race is fixed

This commit cleans up a whole bunch of places where the implicit
current exception was used. Most of them were harmless as there was no
IO between the catching and the reraising, but given that merely
logging can cause the problem, I'd rather not have a bunch of
landmines laying around the codebase.

Bug 1181146

Change-Id: If63743c33c3ef025c2247f869186ff6ff99b9c59
'}]
commit_message:
Fix race in reraising exceptions.

If you're using eventlet and have code like this:

    except SomeException as err:
        log_this_error(err)
        raise

then you're vulnerable to a race condition that could cause the
reraise to fail. What happens is that log_this_error() does some
socket IO (e.g. to syslog), and that IO gives eventlet an opportunity
to trampoline to a different greenthread, and by the time your
greenthread resumes, the current exception has been cleared, so the
bare "raise" statement causes its own exception.

The fix is simple: don't use the implicit current exception.

    except SomeException as err:
        log_this_error(err)
        raise err   # <--- now the race is fixed

This commit cleans up a whole bunch of places where the implicit
current exception was used. Most of them were harmless as there was no
IO between the catching and the reraising, but given that merely
logging can cause the problem, I'd rather not have a bunch of
landmines laying around the codebase.

Bug 1181146

Change-Id: If63743c33c3ef025c2247f869186ff6ff99b9c59

'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2013-05-10 21:56:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

i like some of the moving the v3 tests to a subdirectory, i'm mixed on this v2 stuff, but i am not very happy with the naming scheme

in general, i am not very into adding the subdirectories as i feel arbitrary subdirectories are better at hiding things then they are at showing useful structure, just prefixing the tests and leaving them in the same directory would be more beneficial in my book, and even that can be annoying if the prefixes aren't chosen well and makes scanning over the full list of tests more difficult

the problem i am trying to get at is that it is much easier to put something in a closet and never touch it once you drop it in a subdirectory.

the naming scheme stuff i have problems with is X_tests.py and test_X.py stuff, using similar names with different meanings is confusing, and from what it sounds like you probably want the X_tests.py stuff in the base_X.py part. 

I also don't like base_X.py, I think, for example, that the test_backend.py + test_backend_sql.py did a fine enough job at showing that test_backend_sql.py was a subclass of test_backend.py.

The "runability" of the tests within a given file seems best defined in the code of the file not the naming of the file, it is easy to make tests not runnable by using the existing mixin structure that we've been using already

tl;dr: i'd like to change the naming scheme of the files, i think v3 deserves a directory (because i'd like to hide it) but not sure on others yet'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-05-11 01:37:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I obviously disagree on the subdirectory thing. This may be true if you have just a single directory (like v3) that you never want to see again, but at the moment i have patches to create directories v2, v3, server, client, middleware, auth and legacy. You're going to love this series. Honestly middleware, auth and legacy i don't care that much about because i haven't been messing with those tests. 

Part of the reason for this is the mess of dependencies that are really not clear or in any way enforced by the current scheme or prefixing. This dependency mingling also makes it really difficult to optimize test groups. 

Regarding runability, that's at least partially true. But taking for example test_backend, in nose's scheme this would imply a file which tests backend. It doesn't. The actual runnable tests are implemented by test_backend_x. This is fine when you understand it but not obvious to someone trying to figure it out. 

Now the naming scheme i'm very interested in alternatives as i'm not completely happy with it either. For nose actual runnable tests are test_x.py, other files are support.

I went with base_x as it just seems a bit safer and easier to edit than having multiple base.py. I guess i could put it in __init__.py but honestly the path setup in tests is a bit off and i didn't want to trust it. I'd appreciate other suggestions. 

I went with x_tests.py as having just v2.py in this folder, or for example just catalog.py in tests/v3/ seemed incorrect.

tl;dr I'd love some better naming scheme suggestions, the tests are a mess and i think this is a better way of organizing them than prefixing that make it obvious _to newcomers_ what is going on."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-25 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-25 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

fixed pep8 issues'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-03 16:55:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Do not merge

I really don't like having two different ways this can work.  If the deletion fails, it may be that those resources are still in use.

We need to just fix whatever is causing it to fail."}, {'account_id': 7451, 'date': '2013-05-03 17:31:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Russell, thanks for the comment. Consider the case where the instance deletion fails because of a problem with the infrastructure that is not the fault of the user. If the instance is counted as part of the user's quota, the user is then penalized for that problem. I think that even if any resources are still in use (e.g the instance still exists and the user can log in to it and use it), counting it as part of the user's quota and billing the user for the instance is not really fair, because it's not the user's fault that the instance is left in that state. The user submitted the delete request and has no way of turning it back. While it's true that the user can work around that situation by issuing another delete request through the API (that would remove the instance from the quota, even if it's still running), but I don't see the case for requiring the user to perform an additional action."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-03 17:38:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28063/5/check/gate-nova-pep8/25336 : SUCCESS in 00:03:00
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/28063/5/check/gate-nova-docs/19554/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 00:05:44
- http://logs.openstack.org/28063/5/check/gate-nova-python26/20962 : SUCCESS in 00:18:58
- http://logs.openstack.org/28063/5/check/gate-nova-python26-centos6/182 : SUCCESS in 00:12:47 (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/28063/5/check/gate-nova-python27/21050 : SUCCESS in 00:08:40
- http://logs.openstack.org/28063/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/14502 : SUCCESS in 00:44:00
- http://logs.openstack.org/28063/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/14217 : FAILURE in 00:45:57 (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/28063/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/20631 : SUCCESS in 00:21:10

- http://logs.openstack.org/28063/5/check/gate-nova-pylint/11068 : SUCCESS in 00:08:38 (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-05-03 17:39:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Well, one additional purpose of the quota system is to prevent resource exhaustion; it may be unfair to the user to prevent them from creating a new instance, but it would be unfair to everyone if the system became clogged with instances in the "deleting" task state that were not, in fact, deleted…'}, {'account_id': 7451, 'date': '2013-05-03 18:26:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

There's a trade-off between the two kinds of semantics, so I believe that it is reasonable to have an optional switch that allows Nova administrators choose between them.

Also, note that in the current semantics the exhaustion scenario can still happen. In the scenario where instances don't get deleted due to a problem with the infrastructure and get stuck in task_state=deleting, the user can still remove an instance in that state from the quota by issuing the delete API call for the second time. The proposed change merely removes the need for the user to perform an additional action."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-03 18:28:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Kevin:  I don't really believe that individual user's quotas could ever be used to protect against system level resource exhaustion.  That would seem to imply that there is no over-commitment of resources among the various users, and I just can't imagine anyone running a cloud like that.  

Your point does get to the heart of the issue that both you and Russel are raising though - What are the user quotas trying to protect.

IMO its a mechanism to make sure that a single user can't control more that a certain amount of stuff at any point in time - and so once they have given back something to the system (via a delete_) they should be allowed to get something else within their quota.

If we want to have a general mechanism against a DoS of system level resource exhaustion then I'd suggest that needs to be something above and beyond individual quotas. (And overall system transaction rate limiting is probably a bigger issue that resource consumption).

This change isn't saying that bugs which prevent an instance from being deleted shouldn't be tracked down and fixed - and it doesn't do anything to hide such issues from the cloud provider (more the opposite really).  It's just trying to protect users from issues which aren't their's to solve"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-04 19:11:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Do not merge

I don't agree with this.  If I understand correctly, this sounds like a hack to deal with other potential bugs in nova.  We should just fix those bugs.  And FWIW, I think that as long as the instance record exists, it needs to count against the quota."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-06 01:36:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi Chris,

I don't really see the argument that this is a hack rather than addressing the underlying bug - its more of a policy call on to what extent as a cloud provide you want a system issue to be reflected back to the user.    It is protected by a flag that allows the current behavior by default.

However looking at the other comments we don't seem to be moving towards agreement on that, so lets stand back and look at the problem: 

The trigger for this issue is that the work to handle deletes in the API when a host is down still hasn't completely closed the window for an instance to get stuck in a Deleting state. If the delete request comes in during the window after a compute host has failed but before  the service timeout - in that case the delete will still be queued for the compute host rather than processes in the API layer.  

Can you give us some indication of how you'd like to see this addressed ?"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-06 06:28:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

This feels like a hack to me because of the commit reason stating "This is relevant when deletion fails...".  But, setting that aside, there are problems with this patch, anyway.  When this new flag is enabled, you're re-creating this bug: 1098380.  Deletes were always done in the API before, and you cannot reasonably keep quotas in sync unless you only decrement them when the instance is deleted from the DB successfully.

Take the case you present in your commit reason.. with your patch:  User does delete.  Quota is decremented.  Delete fails.  User does delete again.  Quota is decremented again.  Now quotas are out of sync.

As far as how I think you should address this?  If you've got a downed compute node, you fix it.  When it comes back up, the delete will be processed and quotas decremented.  And if the user does another delete after the "downed" time period in between all of this, that'll also resolve it (like you mention).

Somewhat of a side bar:  I actually dislike the 'delete in API if compute node is determined to be down'.  nova has no way of knowing why the node is down.  The hypervisor could be up and nova-compute could be down.  Now someone can have a free instance to DDoS from for a while.  The IP that was used could be assigned to someone else and you end up with 2 instances on the network with the same IP.. which won't work so well.  Etc.  I feel like any sort of infrastructure issues should be solved with tools and by someone that can determine what the correct course of action is.

But anyway... again kind of a side bar... (But you asked how I think this should work :),  I think we should be casting all deletes to nova-conductor.  Ie, nova-api just sets 'deleting' task state and passes the message to nova-conductor.  nova-conductor can do things like rpc.calls vs rpc.casts to nova-compute... and decide what to do on failures, etc.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-07 16:10:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Chris,

I take your point about needing to keep the quotas in sync - so what if instead of actually changing the reservations we made it so that it was possible to set a flag to ignore instances on their way to oblivion when calculating how much free quota was available ?

On the delete in the API leaving the network in a bad state - I *think* Quantum this is less of an issue as its independent of the compute host.  With Nova net in multi-host then I think the API delete will still fail when it comes to try and talk to the network-manager (maybe this defeats the point of a delete in the API for nova net) ?'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-09 03:40:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

That was the one thing I thought of that could help:  keeping track with each instance whether or not it's counting against quota.. so you know when (not) to remove it.  However, in order for it things to remain in sync,  you'll need to update the quota tables AND the instance in the same DB transaction.  And I don't believe there to be an easy way to do this right now.

As far as quantum... yeah, I think delete in general is hosed no matter what if quantum is down.  This why I think the answer when infrastructure is broken is.... fix the infrastructure.  I don't see much value in releasing the quota early.  No matter what, you probably need to fix the infrastructure in a timely manner... and that makes the need for the early quota release a rather moot point.  (Just my opinion)

Where I start to question myself is instances in ERROR.  I could see one not wanting those to count against the quota.  But there's a lot of work to get that to work properly, too. :)  We need to track whether instance counts against quota or not with every instance.  And you need to possibly add the instance to the quota if any code "revives" the instance from ERROR (ie, a reboot can sometimes make ERROR -> ACTIVE)... and all sorts of fun stuff.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-11 01:43:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Chris,

What I was thinking of in changing the query that counts instances to be measured against quota to skip those in "Deleting" wouldn't need a synchronized update to the DB at all (or any update come to that) - it would just skip those instances.

I don't think you can apply the same logic to instances in an Error state because the user can bring those back into life via rebuild.  Deleting is different simply because the user has no way to bring the instance back.

I guess one further alternative would be to allow an option to change the ownership of instances to another (system) project at the start of the delete, so that whatever happens they no longer appear in that user's lists & quotas, etc.  However I'm worried about how hard it would be to do this cleanly and keep the DB consistent, esp as it would also need to transfer ownership of other objects like Quantum ports.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-25 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-25 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-02 17:13:06.000000000', 'message': "Add flag to release instance from quota before deletion

Add release_instance_quota_before_deletion flag. If set to true, don't
wait for the instance to be actually deleted to release the user's
quota. Delete the instance after the user submits the delete request but
before the actual deletion process starts. This is relevant when
deletion fails due to a problem with the infrastructure and the instance
gets stuck in task_state=deleting and vm_state=active. With that flag
set to false, the instance will still count against the user's quota

commit_message:
Add flag to release instance quota before deletion

Add release_instance_quota_before_deletion flag. If set to true, don't
wait for the instance to be actually deleted to release the user's
quota. Delete the instance after the user submits the delete request but
before the actual deletion process starts. This is relevant when
deletion fails due to a problem with the infrastructure and the instance
gets stuck in task_state=deleting and vm_state=active. With that flag
set to false, the instance will still count against the user's quota
(until the user submits the delete request again, which would release
the quota). With the flag set to true, the instance will no longer count
against the quota.

Fixes: bug #1172764
Change-Id: I6a183859900b0303eb4166bfd6d5ad1f16972fe4

Remove explicit version dependency for old boto version, as this
won't work with the Fedora packaged cloud-init, and heat no longer

Change-Id: Iaf340b4793fdf7ffc3f9b3d0197ca9f6ba6f42fe

commit_message:
F18 openshift tdls, remove boto pip install

Remove explicit version dependency for old boto version, as this
won't work with the Fedora packaged cloud-init, and heat no longer
requires this version, so we should use the Fedora boto package

Change-Id: Iaf340b4793fdf7ffc3f9b3d0197ca9f6ba6f42fe

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-14 22:54:02.000000000', 'message': 'Make NFS share selection more intelligent.

Make the NFS share selection more intelligent by using a used_ratio
and oversub_ratio to determine the valid target.  The used_ratio
is a hard-cap of maximum "actual" used space, oversub_ratio allows
for oversubscription of the share based upon the apparant-allocated
space for sparse files.

New options added:
* nfs_used_ratio:
    Float representation of the maximum allowed usage (e.g. 0.95
    calculated by available_space / total_space) before the share
    is no longer concidered a valid target.  Default: 0.95

* nfs_oversub_ratio:
    Float representation of the oversubscriotion ratio allowed when
    utilizing sparse files (determined via "du").  This gets
    multiplied against the total_capacity before comparing the
    apparant space used by the backing volume files.  Default
    ratio is 1.0 (meaning reserved/allocated space cannot exceed
    total space available on the mount).

bp nfs-share-selection-logic-improvement

Change-Id: I3572e106eb4c794b08bf6f499e2da2d494c4072d
'}, {'created': '2013-05-20 20:45:10.000000000', 'message': 'Make NFS share selection more intelligent.

    multiplied against the total_capacity before comparing the
    apparant space used by the backing volume files.  Default
    ratio is 1.0 (meaning reserved/allocated space cannot exceed
    total space available on the mount).

DocImpact: New Configuration Options / Removal of Config Option

bp nfs-share-selection-logic-improvement

Change-Id: I3572e106eb4c794b08bf6f499e2da2d494c4072d
'}]
commit_message:
Make NFS share selection more intelligent.

Make the NFS share selection more intelligent by using a used_ratio
and oversub_ratio to determine the valid target.  The used_ratio
is a hard-cap of maximum "actual" used space, oversub_ratio allows
for oversubscription of the share based upon the apparant-allocated
space for sparse files.

Removed Options: nfs_disk_util

New options added:
* nfs_used_ratio:
    Float representation of the maximum allowed usage (e.g. 0.95
    calculated by available_space / total_space) before the share
    is no longer concidered a valid target.  Default: 0.95

* nfs_oversub_ratio:
    Float representation of the oversubscriotion ratio allowed when
    utilizing sparse files (determined via "du").  This gets
    multiplied against the total_capacity before comparing the
    apparant space used by the backing volume files.  Default
    ratio is 1.0 (meaning reserved/allocated space cannot exceed
    total space available on the mount).

DocImpact: New Configuration Options / Removal of Config Option

bp nfs-share-selection-logic-improvement

Change-Id: I3572e106eb4c794b08bf6f499e2da2d494c4072d

Clones copy over the attributes from the source volume,
we want to keep some admin data like source-volid and if

after the clone operation and update this info.

Change-Id: I903fe6f8a57880abad8d315d091c1e57624a519c

"}, {'created': '2013-05-24 15:07:49.000000000', 'message': "ModifyVolume attributes on Clone.

Clones copy over the attributes from the source volume,

Change-Id: I903fe6f8a57880abad8d315d091c1e57624a519c

commit_message:
ModifyVolume attributes on Clone.

Clones copy over the attributes from the source volume,
we want to keep some admin data like source-volid and if
it's a clone or not.  To do that we just need to call modifyvolume
after the clone operation and update this info.

Change-Id: I903fe6f8a57880abad8d315d091c1e57624a519c

bump...can this get a review please'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-05-21 08:45:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

as a note, this will definitely break folsom compatibility. With folsom I was getting the error: 

debug: Puppet::Type::Keystone_service::ProviderKeystone: Executing '/usr/bin/keystone --endpoint http://127.0.0.1:35357/v2.0/ service-list'
err: /Stage[main]/Glance::Keystone::Auth/Keystone_service[glance]: Could not evaluate: Execution of '/usr/bin/keystone --endpoint http://127.0.0.1:35357/v2.0/ service-list' returned 1: Expecting a token provided via either --token or env[SERVICE_TOKEN]'

  and the code sets OS_SERVICE_TOKEN

that being said, I am more than ready to stop supporting folsom, I would just ask that we mention in the commit message that is does break folsom support.

I verified that this patch works for initial configuration of users, that I can modify a password, and that those password were not sent to the puppet logs.

I did notice that the ability to list of keystone_users was broken:

    > puppet resource keystone_user
Could not run: Execution of '/usr/bin/keystone --os-auth-url http://127.0.0.1:35357/v2.0/ token-get' returned 1: Expecting a password provided via either --os-password, env[OS_PASSWORD], or prompted response

in fact, any puppet resource operation on keystone_user is broken if I do not provide a password."}, {'account_id': 1926, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:02:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1926, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

thanks Dan, new version uploaded'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:13:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Manage updates to keystone user password with keystone_user

Fix bug 1170380

o Test if the current password works and if not reset it allowing users
  to reset passwords with puppet
o Also move admin token from command line of keystone command in
  favour of using a env variable
o Note : this will break folsom support

Change-Id: I4bae9cad767cdd141ae76343298f7ac43c2a1f90

Then you'd have the auth URL and either the storage URL returned or knowledge of the fact that no storage URl was returned. Does that make sense?"}, {'account_id': 7008, 'date': '2013-05-23 04:44:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Would you prefer the 'increase the entire library's logging by 33% by always printing response headers (for requests that succeed), (since headers seem to be kinda important to swift's operation as a whole)' option or the 'add odd-ball logging to get_auth()' option? A single call to Connection:head_account() (without a pre-existing token) currently has output that looks like this (if the logger's level is set to DEBUG): (succeeding) swiftclient: DEBUG: REQ: curl -i http://192.168.22.50/v1/AUTH_1369246720897245 -X GET swiftclient: DEBUG: RESP STATUS: 200 swiftclient: DEBUG: REQ: curl -i http://192.168.22.50/v1/AUTH_1369246720897245 -I -H "X-Auth-Token: AUTH_tk8831caaec8b44a0784160821dc389453" swiftclient: DEBUG: RESP STATUS: 204 (or failing) swiftclient: DEBUG: REQ: curl -i None -X GET swiftclient: DEBUG: RESP STATUS: 401 swiftclient: DEBUG: RESP BODY:

Unauthorized

This server could not verify that you are authorized to access the document you requested.

swiftclient: DEBUG: REQ: curl -i None -X GET swiftclient: DEBUG: RESP STATUS: 401 swiftclient: DEBUG: RESP BODY:

Unauthorized

This server could not verify that you are authorized to access the document you requested.

commit_message:
log get_auth request url instead of x-storage-url

because if the request gets a 4xx error, then the url will be None, and that's just confusing.

Change-Id: I62729364b9bd279498909dc5cd0d2a1ec5fcd70d

commit_message:
Implement SecurityGroupIds property for instances

Currently handling SecurityGroups and SecurityGroupIds the same exact
way, that is both are passed directly to nova. If one wishes to pass
a security group by parameter of a group to be created in the template,
it must be in the format of <stackname>.<security group name> since
there's no way to determine the ID beforehand.

Fixes bug #1163991

Change-Id: I26bb43ee89806cefc92ba2d0319340c4cd56ed06

commit_message:
Use UUIDs for Quantum security groups

Quantum security groups are referenced by ID and supports duplicate
names, so having the ID available helps to avoid searching for it
when needed.

Change-Id: Idff9245b9848083029dd47fb2253a64b0c5de523

commit_message:
Make IDs for resources unique to ensure tests pass

There were some duplicated IDs being used, specifically with
security groups.

Change-Id: Icf741e42d9dcca922f8944fad546d9db040612ba

commit_message:
Change SecurityGroups to be passed directly to nova

This changes SecurityGroups to return the complete name
of a resource (stack.name).

Change-Id: I945f1213b3ddcb5550e7b4ed3d982d4ee7c4e912

[{'created': '2013-05-24 16:33:53.000000000', 'message': 'Add options to send user-defined metric

This allows the user to specify an arbitrary metric in their
template, and send the number based on some data they can
generate, e.g for openshift node occupancy data

Change-Id: Iaa38614b8db3665f9fb340fd92b67b6f7a47b206
'}]
commit_message:
Add options to send user-defined metric

This allows the user to specify an arbitrary metric in their
template, and send the number based on some data they can
generate, e.g for openshift node occupancy data

Change-Id: Iaa38614b8db3665f9fb340fd92b67b6f7a47b206

- multi line docstring should start with a summary (flake8 H404)

Change-Id: I69b414395930bda739aa01b785ac619fa8bb7d9b
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup docstrings (flake8 H401, H402, H403, H404)

- docstring should not start with a space (flake8 H401)
- one line docstring needs punctuation (flake8 H402)
- multi line docstring end on new line (flake8 H403)
- multi line docstring should start with a summary (flake8 H404)

Change-Id: I69b414395930bda739aa01b785ac619fa8bb7d9b

commit_message:
Sync shadow table for 179 migration

To be able to use db archiving our table and shadow table should
have the same columns.

fixes bug 1179497

Change-Id: I001f31a5efa07c80acd1ad513369456fb8c3cb44

commit_message:
Remove copy paste from 179 migration

We have utils to change type of deleted column.
So just remove copy paste.

Approach is the same, and code is almost the same, so it
is safe to change old migration.

Change-Id: I5422b484c1270468c5dec0395466a0691acb772f

commit_message:
Sync shadow table for 175 and 176 migration

To be able to use db archiving our table and shadow table should
have the same columns.

fixes bug 1176443

Change-Id: I461a6d0e3661e2b60c266dffff38e3317784c113

commit_message:
Improve unit test output

The doctest output can be a little cryptic, with output related to the
doctest framework and not about the doctests themselves.  Make the
output a little clearer.

* Print entire doctest line, including code
* Print reason when fail to trigger rule

Change-Id: Iccbf1401e3a31da998fbc261bf8d20836af877d0
Reviewed-on: https://review.openstack.org/29741
Reviewed-by: Sean Dague <sean@dague.net>
Approved: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Reviewed-by: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Tested-by: Jenkins

commit_message:
Stop referencing nova HACKING guide

Since this originally came from nova, the docstrings referred to the
nova HACKING guide, now that this is a separate project refer to the
OpenStack HACKING guide instead.

Change-Id: I38c0791dfca73cf3ae114fc7292c41c0670a3987
Reviewed-on: https://review.openstack.org/29739
Reviewed-by: Sean Dague <sean@dague.net>
Approved: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Reviewed-by: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Tested-by: Jenkins

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-13 14:26:09.000000000', 'message': "Change db `deleted` column type utils

Move and refactor methods from 152_migration that allows us to change
type of deleted column to type of id.

There are 2 methods:

utils.change_deleted_column_type_to_id_type() method
This method change type of `deleted` column from Boolen to
type of `id`. This method allows us to do it in generic way
for all backends. It fix problem with sqlite, that doesn't
allow any operation with columns that have CheckConstraints.
And columns with BoolenConstraints have CheckConstraints
(value in (0, 1)). So for sqlite it works through shadow tables.
For others dbs it works throuhg alter table.

utils.change_deleted_column_type_to_boolean_type() methods
This method allows us to revert result of previous method.
Useful for downgrade.

In global these methods could be very useful in olso for other
projects. This is a first step that allows us to create unique
constraints when we are using soft delete.
(Create UC on (column, deleted))

Also it will be useful in nova to remove copy past from 179
migration. Add new migration that will fix also shadow_cells table.
And also there are baremetal tables that should be also migrated.

blueprint db-common-migration-and-utils

Change-Id: Ie14351c52eb50182e6460c97e257395ce2adb8b0
"}, {'created': '2013-05-22 16:03:03.000000000', 'message': "Change db `deleted` column type utils

commit_message:
Change db `deleted` column type utils

Move and refactor methods from 152_migration that allows us to change
type of deleted column to type of id.

There are 2 methods:

utils.change_deleted_column_type_to_id_type() method
This method change type of `deleted` column from Boolean to
type of `id`. This method allows us to do it in generic way
for all backends. It fix problem with sqlite, that doesn't
allow any operation with columns that have CheckConstraints.
And columns with Boolean type have CheckConstraints
(value in (0, 1)). So for sqlite it works through shadow tables.
For others dbs it works though alter table.

utils.change_deleted_column_type_to_boolean_type() methods
This method allows us to revert result of previous method.
Useful for downgrade.

In global these methods could be very useful in olso for other
projects. This is a first step that allows us to create unique
constraints when we are using soft delete.
(Create UC on (column, deleted))

Also it will be useful in nova to remove copy past from 179
migration. Add new migration that will fix also shadow_cells table.
And also there are baremetal tables that should be also migrated.

blueprint db-common-migration-and-utils

Change-Id: Ie14351c52eb50182e6460c97e257395ce2adb8b0

commit_message:
Fix tests for sqlalchemy utils

This fix tests to be able to run it with postgresql and mysql.

Some tests should be run only on sqlite

Method create_shadow_tables raises different exception in different
backends (when we try to create duplicate table):
In postgresql it is ProgrammingError
In sqlite and mysql it is OperationalError
So create new Exception that will be raised in both cases.

bp db-common-migration-and-utils

Change-Id: I11be23106bc01bd3c72dad30edfb31a17177bb34

[{'created': '2013-04-10 12:57:09.000000000', 'message': "Add GLANCE_LOCALEDIR env variable

Part of fixing bug #995287

Syncs these two commits from oslo-incubator:

  Support overriding oslo localedir too
  Add a gettextutils.install() helper function

to get a new gettextutils.install() function which allows the default
localedir to be overwritten via an environment variable.

Note that gettextutils.install() must be called before any other glance
modules are imported since some modules attempt to translate strings
at import time (e.g. the help strings for config options in config.py).
This is broken and inefficient, but fixing it involves adding something
like spinx's l_() function and would be very invaisve.

Change-Id: I86562b3a65d371673bb21f7179eecc7602bc0775
"}, {'created': '2013-05-08 08:27:55.000000000', 'message': "Add GLANCE_LOCALEDIR env variable

Part of fixing bug #995287

Syncs these two commits from oslo-incubator:

  Support overriding oslo localedir too
  Add a gettextutils.install() helper function

to get a new gettextutils.install() function which allows the default
localedir to be overwritten via an environment variable.

Note that gettextutils.install() must be called before any other glance
modules are imported since some modules attempt to translate strings
at import time (e.g. the help strings for config options in config.py).
This is broken and inefficient, but fixing it involves adding something
like spinx's l_() function and would be very invaisve.

Also, note that calling gettextutils.install() in glance.cmd.__init__

Change-Id: I86562b3a65d371673bb21f7179eecc7602bc0775

commit_message:
Add GLANCE_LOCALEDIR env variable

Part of fixing bug #995287

Syncs these two commits from oslo-incubator:

  Support overriding oslo localedir too
  Add a gettextutils.install() helper function

to get a new gettextutils.install() function which allows the default
localedir to be overwritten via an environment variable.

Note that gettextutils.install() must be called before any other glance
modules are imported since some modules attempt to translate strings
at import time (e.g. the help strings for config options in config.py).
This is broken and inefficient, but fixing it involves adding something
like spinx's l_() function and would be very invaisve.

Also, note that calling gettextutils.install() in glance.cmd.__init__
means that no program which uses a different translation domain should
ever import any of the modules under glance.cmd.

Change-Id: I86562b3a65d371673bb21f7179eecc7602bc0775

When devstack creates stack-screenrc, it includes unescaped "
characters that cause failures starting nova-compute.  This fix

commit_message:
Fix screenrc for nova-compute

When devstack creates stack-screenrc, it includes unescaped "
characters that cause failures starting nova-compute.  This fix
changes the " to ' so there isn't a conflict.

Fixes bug 1183114

Change-Id: I7830879d56f1ac20950aace46dd3b72d209986ce

commit_message:
Set up 'compute_task' conductor namespace.

This patch sets up a new API to be exposed by the nova-conductor
service.  The existing methods exposed by conductor are all proxy
operations on behalf of compute nodes.

For Havana, we have plans to add methods that go the other direction.
Operations initiated by the API will be processed by the conductor,
which will include telling one or more compute nodes what to do.  By
putting all operations of this form in their own API, it will keep
things a bit more clearly separated.

Change-Id: Ifa3d443b9bd7f406a7a3bd837351bc689bf2b6c8

The previous commit created an incompatibility in using new nova
client with older nova server. Nova client needs to be always
releasable, and work with all nova server API versions out there.

'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Support force update quota"

This reverts commit e8b665edbfcd86488f75ed0b79dafdedbf8f5950.

The previous commit created an incompatibility in using new nova
client with older nova server. Nova client needs to be always
releasable, and work with all nova server API versions out there.

Fixes bug #1173353

Change-Id: I2c07d109af4a35bc3b98dedaf991d5d3cc6fdd3b

Hi Flavio, 
Thanks for your comments, will implement the suggestions shortly.'}, {'account_id': 7217, 'date': '2013-05-23 12:37:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 7217, 'date': '2013-05-23 12:48:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (3 inline comments)

Implemented suggestions from inline comments. 

From Flavio's previous comment: "I was also wondering whether the user should be notified when stdin is closed / open and empty. (A warning would be enough)."

In order to do this, it is necessary to know whether input via stdin is required. In order to know that, we need to know the current status of the image. However Alex asked me to take an image status check out in a comment on patch set 3. 

I could re-add a test for image state, and warn the user if data is required but not provided, but should that be done in this change, a new change or a dependant change?'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-23 12:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Hey, thanks for taking care of this so quickly.

I was thinking something like:

  if not sys.stdin.isatty() and stat_result.st_size == 0:
     LOG.warn("You're doing it wrong :D")

So that the user know that nothing is actually being sent because nothing can be read.

Does that make sense?

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:23:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27536/8/check/gate-python-glanceclient-pep8/765 : SUCCESS in 39s

- http://logs.openstack.org/27536/8/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/17701 : FAILURE in 45m 10s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/27536/8/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/24726 : SUCCESS in 19m 07s
- http://logs.openstack.org/27536/8/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5485 : FAILURE in 11m 28s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 7217, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:25:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

The user may not be doing anything wrong though. If the operation doesn't require data (metadata change for example), then it shouldn't matter whether stdin is a tty or not and whether it is open/closed/empty. This bug came up because our internal tests presented an empty stdin to glanceclient for an operation that doesn't require data, would be a shame to have an unnecessary warning each time. 

We could minimise this by only giving a warning if the image is in queued state, as that is when it is most likely that the user intends to upload data, however that is still a guess as metadata operations are still valid on queued images. 

The cleanest way I can think of is to have a parameter  (eg --data) that specifies a path/url/whatever to an to be uploaded and allow the user to specify '-' for read stdin. If --data isn't specified then the client doesn't attempt to read data from anywhere. I realise thats quite a large change to how the client works though :-/"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:30:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

mmh, Fair enough. I guess the case we should care about is the one you mentioned, that is, image-related operations. We can discuss this on IRC and see what's more convenient."}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2013-05-24 15:55:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Don't attempt to read stdin if it is empty.

 * Check for available data size in v1/shell.py/_set_data_field, don't
   read if 0.
 * Add test_shell.py including tests for 3x stdin scenarios:
	* closed
 	* open and empty
	* open with data

Change-Id: I6ff65b0e226be509de9cd3f021560081529283b0
Fixes: bug #1173044

commit_message:
xenapi - cleanup network configuration

The Xenserver/XCP part of devstack was configuring the hypervisor's
connectivity to the outer world, by adding VLANs, and physical
interfaces to the virtual networks. It added a lot of complexity, and
made it hard to get started with XenServer. This patch removes that
extra complexity, so it is left as an exercise for the user.

Related to blueprint blueprint xenapi-devstack-cleanup

Change-Id: If3367335c3da8621d0afe1f6cae77511fbdbb3e2

[{'created': '2013-05-23 18:05:54.000000000', 'message': "Better error message on malformed request url

The existing error message just said 'malformed url' which isn't
super-helpful. The new version expalins that the project ID in the URL is not
matching what's being passed in with the context.

Change-Id: I8e5b71fcd51ab3628425b53356f9671f3a2402c0
"}]
commit_message:
Better error message on malformed request url

The existing error message just said 'malformed url' which isn't
super-helpful. The new version expalins that the project ID in the URL is not
matching what's being passed in with the context.

Change-Id: I8e5b71fcd51ab3628425b53356f9671f3a2402c0

commit_message:
Implement support for grizzly release.

Added {public,admin}_endpoint to keystone.conf and updates paste configuration.

Change-Id: I8fd87d4f19fa3c23edbaef674d7b4d908722b0f1

commit_message:
Move parse search logic outside from builder

Dramatic part of RingBuilder.search_devs which parse a complex format
of a search device string moved to the swift-ring-builder script.
Instead, the search_devs has a simple interface to search devices.

blueprint argparse-in-swift-ring-builder

Change-Id: If3dd77b297b474fb9a058e4693fef2dfb11fca3d

commit_message:
Switch to Semantic Versioning

Configure the identity coobook with the new versioning scheme we
discusssed on the ML. It will start out at 7.0.0(7th OpenStack
release).

Fixes: Bug 1183687
Change-Id: I590916cde469a338a9e5a43a29176fff797f3d52
