Sync a bunch of changes from oslo-incubator that are either obviously
safe, add new code that ironic doesn't use or modifies existing code
that ironic doesn't use.

The commits are:

  fe2f108 Enable hacking H702 localization test
  0a14e1d Enable hacking H703: Multiple positional placeholders
  a4a6789 Pass backdoor_port to services being launched
  d5e57e9 Add DynamicLoopCall timers to ThreadGroups
  926b3e9 Fixes import order nits
  a514693 Removes len() on empty sequence evaluation
  ab6b2d4 Line wrapper becomes to long when expanded.
  b873454 Added convenience APIs for lockutils
  562cc68 Stylistic improvements from quantum-rootwrap
  3893ef8 Import trycmd and ssh_execute from nova.

Change-Id: I0a900b35e4bb4ddd56ecc083a30b0b1fba2e8b04
"}]
commit_message:
Sync safe changes from oslo-incubator

Sync a bunch of changes from oslo-incubator that are either obviously
safe, add new code that ironic doesn't use or modifies existing code
that ironic doesn't use.

The commits are:

  fe2f108 Enable hacking H702 localization test
  0a14e1d Enable hacking H703: Multiple positional placeholders
  a4a6789 Pass backdoor_port to services being launched
  d5e57e9 Add DynamicLoopCall timers to ThreadGroups
  926b3e9 Fixes import order nits
  a514693 Removes len() on empty sequence evaluation
  ab6b2d4 Line wrapper becomes to long when expanded.
  b873454 Added convenience APIs for lockutils
  562cc68 Stylistic improvements from quantum-rootwrap
  3893ef8 Import trycmd and ssh_execute from nova.

Change-Id: I0a900b35e4bb4ddd56ecc083a30b0b1fba2e8b04

[{'created': '2013-05-23 22:29:16.000000000', 'message': 'engine : PoC initial template_format parser for HOT template

Based on the draft templates posted, this is a super-minimal example
of where we could potentially plug in the DSL/HOT translator in a
non-intrusive way.  Initially the translation will be from HOT to
our internal template model, and over time, we could potentially
use a similar _parse_cfn function to somewhat deaws-ify the engine.

This is a DRAFT patch to promote discussion about the approach and
to provide an example of potentially where we can do this for those
interested in persuing the alternate-template implementation

Change-Id: Id20d9487296d319204bf76914e4fcec05f5885d2

commit_message:
engine : PoC initial template_format parser for HOT template

Based on the draft templates posted, this is a super-minimal example of
where we can plug in the DSL/HOT translator in a non-intrusive way.
Initially the translation will be from HOT to our internal template
model, and over time, we could potentially use a similar _parse_cfn
function to somewhat de-aws-ify the engine.

provides a starting point for blueprint: hot-hello-world

Change-Id: Id20d9487296d319204bf76914e4fcec05f5885d2

messages:
[{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2013-05-14 12:48:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2013-05-14 13:32:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-05-14 13:44:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This appears to be an enhancement that doesn't meet the guidelines stated at https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/StableBranch#Appropriate_Fixes"}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2013-05-14 14:49:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The title of the commit can be confusing but the real reason of this change is, that "boot on volume" is broken in grizzly when you use nfs or netapp backend, it silency failed with a backtrace with a "NotImplemented" exception.

This is why I propose this change to grizzly backport, to fix this issue.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-05-17 19:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Understood, but my estimation is that this still falls more in the category of "enhancement" than "bugfix" and so isn't appropriate...  I don't think major driver functionality is expected to change in a stable branch.

If it is considered, we need to consider it along with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29591/'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-20 10:04:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agree with Eric, this patch doesn't seem to fit the requirements."}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2013-05-23 20:09:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2013-05-24 12:39:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Ok, this doesn't need more discutions I guess. :)"}]

commit_message:
Initial heat orchestration tests.

This does a creat/list/show/delete of a stack with no resources.

It should run fast and is suitable for gating, since it doesn't
create any nova instances.

I'd consider it to be a smoke test. It confirms that heat-api
can communicate with heat-engine, and that heat-engine has
a properly configured database.

Blueprint: add-basic-heat-tests
Change-Id: Id249a34c3a28e1e69d9eb000c6c5c2e82d619178

commit_message:
Remove quantum-specific dkms workaround.

This is not specific to openvswitch and is more useful in the base
element as a generic script that ensures we have valid modules for
all combinations of installed dkms modules and kernels.

Change-Id: Iefe5fb187b32f7ac2189d2cf242cfaac2c1024fb

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-24 11:24:04.000000000', 'message': 'Build all dkms modules near the end of the image build.

Work around ordering issues that cause dkms modules to not always
be built for all installed kernels, add a post-install.d script to
the base element that will force the issue.
(Note that any module/kernel pairs with a pre-existing valid
module will not be rebuilt, so this should not impact performance
unnecessarily)

Change-Id: Iccea14c6318014cc7e1fec77e71c14a224f7b76e
'}]
commit_message:
Build all dkms modules near the end of the image build.

Work around ordering issues that cause dkms modules to not always
be built for all installed kernels, add a post-install.d script to
the base element that will force the issue.
(Note that any module/kernel pairs with a pre-existing valid
module will not be rebuilt, so this should not impact performance
unnecessarily)

Change-Id: Iccea14c6318014cc7e1fec77e71c14a224f7b76e

[{'created': '2013-05-12 17:47:07.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi - use management network to reach OS VM

Devstack used the HOST_IP_IFACE to reach the OpenStack VM through ssh.
This patch changes this behavior, so that the IP address of the
interface connected to the management network will be used.

Related to blueprint xenapi-devstack-cleanup

Change-Id: I7f34d973870792d60a33ea512901d9b0d422150b
'}]
commit_message:
xenapi - use management network to reach OS VM

Devstack used the HOST_IP_IFACE to reach the OpenStack VM through ssh.
This patch changes this behavior, so that the IP address of the
interface connected to the management network will be used.

Related to blueprint xenapi-devstack-cleanup

Change-Id: I7f34d973870792d60a33ea512901d9b0d422150b

When Quantum auth_token configuration were moved to quantum.conf,
the temporary logic to disable auth_token in api-paste.ini was added
to avoid gating test failures of patches based on the version with
api-paste.ini auth_token configurations.
This temporary logic is no longer needed.

Change-Id: I539301a338d5ada01c83af5e9cf203849a67c6c1
'}]
commit_message:
Remove temporary logic for Quantum auth_token transition

When Quantum auth_token configuration were moved to quantum.conf,
the temporary logic to disable auth_token in api-paste.ini was added
to avoid gating test failures of patches based on the version with
api-paste.ini auth_token configurations.
This temporary logic is no longer needed.

Change-Id: I539301a338d5ada01c83af5e9cf203849a67c6c1

[{'created': '2013-05-21 06:19:53.000000000', 'message': 'use SERVICE_HOST intead of HOST_IP for quantum services

The other services, like nova, glance and cinder, use SERVICE_HOST
instead of HOST_IP to configure their server listening addresses.
This is more friendly to multi-node quantum deployment.

Change-Id: Ibee22ef59d532e8f7004d8e4582015d303d15404
'}]
commit_message:
use SERVICE_HOST intead of HOST_IP for quantum services

The other services, like nova, glance and cinder, use SERVICE_HOST
instead of HOST_IP to configure their server listening addresses.
This is more friendly to multi-node quantum deployment.

Change-Id: Ibee22ef59d532e8f7004d8e4582015d303d15404

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names

From bug report:
Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: Ie0bdb4908f45e47db43e84cd0c5fdc5263c035f4
Fixes: Bug #1179008

It's an optional requirement but I don't know if it's possible to specify that in the current way it works."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-05-18 07:26:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I can't see this packaged for Ubuntu on 12.04 or 12.10."}, {'account_id': 2998, 'date': '2013-05-20 07:24:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Michael, please take into account that a lot of other Python libraries used by Openstack are not packaged for Ubuntu 12.04. I've spent some time to manually check tools/pip-requires for Nova and Requirements projects.

Please consider removing your "-1". 

Nova (8 from 33)
----
oslo.config
websockify
stevedore
python-glanceclient
python-cinderclient
sqlalchemy-migrate
pbr
d2to1
----

Requirements (23 from 68)
----
wsme
websockify
warlock
stevedore
sqlalchemy-migrate
setuptools_git
qpid-python
pyyaml
pytz
python-swiftclient
python-glanceclient
python-cinderclient
pecan
pbr
oslo.config
jsonschema
jsonrpclib
happybase
extras
django_openstack_auth
django_compressor
django>=1.4,<1.6 - Packaged version of Django is 1.3.1
cliff
----'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2013-05-20 16:45:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Indeed, we expended a lot of effort to create the virtualenv-based testing system specifically so that whether a requirement is packaged is not a blocker for OpenStack development.  I don't believe our intention with the requirements repo is to undo that -- but rather to help loop packagers in early and facilitate a dialog between devs and packagers about new deps.  I think that package deps should be favored over non-packaged ones when equivalent functionality exists, but we shouldn't block all non-packaged deps.

(After all, we could just drop all the venv nonsense if we wanted that.)"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-20 19:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

part of the reason for requirements though was to give the distros a chance to weigh in and say "no way, that's insane to package that".

So I think you can +2 something if it's already in the distros. And if not, we really need both a Canonical and Red Hat person at least so say "sure, we can probably handle that".'}, {'account_id': 2998, 'date': '2013-05-21 07:19:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

There is no alternative for using kazoo in driver using kazoo.
And some nice person started maintaining python-kazoo package for Ubuntu 13.10:
https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/kazoo'}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:07:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Generally, I don't see an issue with this.

I'm imagining* that Ubuntu, and maybe other distros.. will not commit to supporting this in their primary offerings as this is to support optional features in Havana (not core functionality).  It is optional, right?

* Could well be wrong, but fundamentally"}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:10:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:13:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Obviously I havent had my caffine this morning.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-05-23 19:39:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2013-05-24 09:28:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-24 09:28:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-24 09:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29242/2/gate/gate-requirements-install/82 : SUCCESS in 9m 56s

commit_message:
Fix networking and nova security group config.

Per bug 1183721 the defaults have nova do the configuration, and
should be changed for OpenStack Networking.

Change-Id: Ie9093f6372df013016235ee8569946c0688125c2

project_id can be different from the user's project in the admin case.

It also looks like there's a mismatch in the original commit between the route in dashboards/admin/projects/urls.py and the ProjectUsageView, tenant_id vs project_id, I suspect those views are broken."}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:49:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:55:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This last patchset only fixes the pep8 error.

Kieran, would you mind clarifying what you mean about the admin use case? The patch is about the project overview and I get the correct project name when I do a csv export as an admin user (depending on the project selected in the drop-down), are you talking about something else?

At this point I'm not seeing issues with the admin project page. Maybe a separate bug should be filed if there's a problem there as well?"}, {'account_id': 5733, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:07:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I'm talking about viewing the usage of a specific project on the admin/projects/<tenant_id>/usage route, via the "View Usage" link.'}, {'account_id': 5733, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:27:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

What I'd really prefer is to revert the commit completely so these three regressions (overview/login, Django 1.4, and specific-tenant usage) are fixed immediately, and there's more time to fix the original patch and give it a thorough review.

That said, it's quite late in my timezone, so do what you will while I get some sleep. :)"}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:28:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:31:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I see, thanks for the link to usages!

I reverted back to the first version of the patch removing the name entirely, and filed bug 1183441 for the issue you pointed out from the admin side.

I'm totally happy with what you suggest as well, reverting the original patch for now and working through the issues with more time and more careful review. Unfortunately I have to leave as well so I'll leave it as is for now. Thanks for the reviews!"}, {'account_id': 5733, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:50:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not merge

I will push through a revert for now unless anyone objects very soon.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 17:18:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Remove the project name from the usage CSV export

tenant_get() is an admin-only function and causes issues when a
regular user attempts to access the overview page.

Fixes bug 1183230

Change-Id: Iba113a40b46acbd4a32e1750eb5ca8c605be5c69

commit_message:
Modify hacking flake8 extension

Move hacking files to dir used by the rest of the projects
Use the hacking factory option to allow for additional checks

Change-Id: If498bb4a2d1ce85c51abd04a559e9106febf4027

This test takes 30s just for the json. I don't see why we need another test class for this, or why it is necessary to create three snapshots to test list_snapshots. Why not just change test_snapshot_create_get_delete to test_snapshot_create_get_list_delete and add a call to list_snapshots?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-05-13 16:04:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This actually does not test anything that is not already tested in /tests/volume/test_volumes_list.py. The operation is GET /volumes. There is no GET /snapshots that is a fundamentally different operation, so I believe the test_volumes_list.py test already fully covers the listing behaviours you wanted to test separately here, and test_volumes_snapshots.py already tests the create/delete process..."}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2013-05-13 22:17:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 00:12:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Add some basic snapshots listing test

Renames "test_snapshot_create_get_delete" into
"test_snapshot_create_get_list_delete" and adds into it some
get and list assertions. By adding the list test in the existing
create_get_delete sequence we introduce a check without slowing
down the test run as we don't need to recreate the initial
volume/snapshot condition.

Change-Id: I56276619be424c91979bed0133152725ea0993df
Implements: blueprint add-snapshot-tests

[{'created': '2013-05-21 23:22:59.000000000', 'message': "Only add logging handlers if there currently aren't any

This corrects an odd problem where Horizon would stand up multiple
client objects, which would cause duplicate/triplicate/dozens of
repeated log lines in its log files, due to multiple identical
handlers being added to the logging object

Fixes Bug 1182678

Change-Id: I198f3ecbb687bff69a06a166574b998cce54f2ac
"}]
commit_message:
Only add logging handlers if there currently aren't any

This corrects an odd problem where Horizon would stand up multiple
client objects, which would cause duplicate/triplicate/dozens of
repeated log lines in its log files, due to multiple identical
handlers being added to the logging object

Fixes Bug 1182678

Change-Id: I198f3ecbb687bff69a06a166574b998cce54f2ac

commit_message:
Add tests list tenant usage

* Get the specified tenant usage with admin user
  and non admin user.
* List the tenant usages with admin user.
* Negative test of fail with tenant empty, invalid date,
  and non admin user.

Partially Implements: blueprint missing-tempest-tests

Change-Id: Ice51c64a99589f50290ea79bf1c17ef8eab85291

commit_message:
Only add logging handlers if there currently aren't any

This corrects an odd problem where Horizon would stand up multiple
client objects, which would cause duplicate/triplicate/dozens of
repeated log lines in its log files, due to multiple identical
handlers being added to the logging object

Fixes Bug 1182678

Change-Id: I1f3bae0a39f28412c99e5d04f4364611f2a5facb

[{'created': '2013-05-16 07:05:48.000000000', 'message': "Implements Cross Service Unified Request id

Including 'correlation_id' middleware from oslo-incubator.
Hooked this middleware in the paste deploy pipeline.
The correlation_id that is generated by the middleware
is added to the RequestContext and gets logged along
with the request_id, to enable more effective debugging
of requests that span multiple services.

Change-Id: I21b27e8dae585345d03d59c125d9e1bbea95f830
Implements: blueprint cross-service-request-id

commit_message:
Importing correlation_id middleware from oslo-incubator

Including 'correlation_id' middleware from oslo-incubator.
Adding this to openstack-common.conf to copy over the middleware to
the location nova/openstack/common/middleware

Change-Id: I21b27e8dae585345d03d59c125d9e1bbea95f830
Implements: blueprint cross-service-request-id

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 23:10:03.000000000', 'message': 'Compatibility for python2.7/python3 modules

According to http://docs.python.org/3.1/whatsnew/3.0.html:

Modules such as StringIO, CStringIO and xmlrpclib are
no longer available so let python-six manage them
to make the best choice for a particualr python version.

Change-Id: I1a073b6126f917b523c96285799b6385ed24ccd9
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-05-08 23:10:48.000000000', 'message': 'Compatibility for python2.7/python3 modules

According to http://docs.python.org/3.1/whatsnew/3.0.html:

Modules such as StringIO, CStringIO and xmlrpclib are
no longer available so let python-six manage them
to make the best choice for a particular python version.

commit_message:
python3: Rename StringIO and ConfigParser imports

According to http://docs.python.org/3.1/whatsnew/3.0.html:

Modules such as StringIO and CStringIO are
no longer available so let python-six manage them
to make the best choice for a particular python version.

Change-Id: I1a073b6126f917b523c96285799b6385ed24ccd9
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-04-29 21:03:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

1) need something for existing accounts (offline account-updater)
2) need to handle DELETE
3) need to handle syncing out of band (e.g. once you add delete's and then one of them 503's)
4) need to handle sharding of millions of accounts

I don't think namespaces are needed.  But more to the point, I don't think they should be a part of this feature.

IMHO, A correct implementation of a process that will keep an api accessible iterable list of all accounts swift is managing would be useful enough to warrant inclusion out of the box - as opposed to pointing operators to "slogging + roll your own interface".  How to relate that data back to your (possibly many) auth systems is something else entirely.'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-04-29 21:54:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Clay

I will add: 
1) offline account-updater 2) DELETE 

3) syncing out of band is already supported as the namespace is just another account and synching is done as it does for any acount

4) need to handle sharding of millions of accounts
This is same as millions of containers in an account or millions of objects in a container.
I don't see a need to do here something different. 

I can remove support for multiple namespaces - yet should we have a single namespace per AUTH system? or have one for the entire system which will be accessible from all AUTH systems :)
I.e. if ther eare reseller prefix of AUTH1 and AUTH2:
Should GET /AUTH1_namespace return all accounts of AUTH1 or all accounts of both?

Being a namespace guy - I prefer the prior, but whatever will help getting to an agreement will do."}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-05-08 11:05:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-08 11:15:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

[{'created': '2013-04-29 14:50:20.000000000', 'message': 'Account Listing

Support for Account Listing by reusing the account servers

Support is optional and controlled by two configuration parameters
  namespace = <a reserved account name for the namespace> or None (default)
  namespace_parts = <the number of parts added to the namespace> or 1 (default)
Setting namespace to None disables the mechanism.

E.g. with:
  namespace = ***
  namespace_parts = 1

Account listing is enabled by listing the namespace
    GET /v1/AUTH_***
    or
    GET /v1/AUTH_***?prefix=ab

DELETE, POST, PUT account operations on the configured namespace are forbidden
PUT container into the configured namespace is forbidden

Implementation is simple as it reuses the account-container relationship to
form an account-namespace relationship.

Daemon for collecting lost accounts is planed as a future enhancement

Implements Bleuprint: Account Listing

Change-Id: Id5b83ef5f87fd5a8d91edce754aad35ad3e80a3a

commit_message:
Account Listing

Support for Account Listing by reusing the account servers

Support is optional and controlled by two configuration parameters
  namespace = <a reserved account name for the namespace> or None
    * None is the default
Setting namespace to None disables the mechanism.

E.g. with:
  namespace = AUTH_***

Account listing is enabled by listing the namespace
    GET /v1/AUTH_***
    or
    GET /v1/AUTH_***?prefix=ab

DELETE, POST, PUT account operations on the configured namespace are
forbidden PUT container into the configured namespace is forbidden

Implementation is simple as it reuses the account-container
relationship to form an account-namespace relationship.

Daemon for collecting lost accounts is planed as a future enhancement

Implements: bleuprint Account Listing

Change-Id: Id5b83ef5f87fd5a8d91edce754aad35ad3e80a3a

Also since this patch didn't modify any db schema, there is no question of failing test_sql_upgrade test."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-04-22 19:15:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not opposed to bringing in the openstack.common code or the changes that add substransactions=True support, however I don't believe it is necessary to add begin/commit/rollback to the public driver interface. This is specific to the SQL driver and only the SQL driver, and belongs as a private interface in that driver only."}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2013-04-23 01:17:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Jay: I totally agree with you, but looking at the current design, adding these 3 methods to the public interface was the quickest, easiest and safest way for handling atomic transactions. In the present design, there is no appropriate place where it is possible to initiate atomic transactions(for a bunch of identity apis) but IMO if we introduce another layer between controller and identity API then for SQL back-end only, it is possible to initiate atomic transaction and this way we can keep subtransactions=True logic private to the SQL back-end. This has a huge impact though and lot of code will be changed.

The other solution as suggested by Dolph is to create a new class for these three unimplemented methods, TransactableDriverMixin (maybe in keystone.common.driver?), implement it in TransactableSqlDriverMixin and have the sql driver(identity/backends/sql.py) extend that and then IMO depending on the type of back-end driver loaded decide to call begin/commit/rollback transaction methods in the handle_atomic_transaction decorator.

Anyone has any suggestions on how to handle atomic transaction in a much better and elegant way?

P.S. We have identified more than 14 APIs which requires attention for handling atomic transactions. Currently we are trying to freeze on the design by fixing create user API, after this patch is accepted by core reviewers, we will implement it for the remaining APIs.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-04-23 02:00:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not merge

We cannot assume that we will have a transactional backend.  The SQL backend is not even the most likely supported, as we have many people deploying with LDAP.  LDAP will not support this form of transactional back end.

Any and all transaction based code must be limited to the SQL driver and cannot change the contract of the other drivers.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-04-23 18:05:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2013-04-24 20:13:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I am very dubious on what this is attempting to do, can you link to other code that is using this technique for handling rollbacks and such? I am more familiar with style of keeping track of transactions that, for example, Google App Engine uses (basically, function context): https://code.google.com/p/googleappengine/source/browse/trunk/python/google/appengine/api/datastore.py#2490

Additionally, I agree with some of the statements above concerning adding this only to the sql backends that support transactions, I don't think the common code need exist.

Once those things are sorted out I am willing to start reviewing the actual implementation (cursory glance looks like i'll have plenty of comments)"}, {'account_id': 6124, 'date': '2013-04-25 09:42:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-25 10:27:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/5/check/gate-keystone-pep8/4814 : SUCCESS
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/25517/5/check/gate-keystone-docs/3188/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/5/check/gate-keystone-python26/3708 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/5/check/gate-keystone-python26-rhel6/262 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/5/check/gate-keystone-python27/3720 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/13553 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/13268 : FAILURE (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/19507 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/5/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/1423 : FAILURE (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 6124, 'date': '2013-04-25 10:50:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@termie info on how we are using transactions/subtransactions can be found here (http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_8/orm/session.html#managing-transactions)'}, {'account_id': 6124, 'date': '2013-04-25 10:52:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Taking all the feedback into consideration, patchset 5 uses a TransactableDriverMixin (Abstract class), which is then implemented in TransactableSQLDriverMixin, this class extends the SQL.Base which is inherited by all the sql backend drivers like identity/backends/sql.py token/backends/sql.py etc. Patchset 5 does not touch any public api or other backends like ldap, kvs etc. 
The decorator "handle_atomic_transaction" should be applied to any public api method for which all db calls should be atomic. This is done by the use of "begin, commit, rollback" methods of the SqlAlchemy Session object. We have used SqlAlchemy subtransactions (nested transactions) to solve atomicity of multiple db calls which touch different tables in the db. If the decorator is not applied, then Session management is done by the default way as it is done in the current/master. The decorator only works when the SQL backend is used and if that sql backend driver has the TransactableSQLDriverMixin. Hence the db logic of all public api calls remains same except for those for which the decorator is applied.

As mentioned above by Tushar Patil, the other solution to this bug would be to add another layer between controller and identity API.

Feedback is welcome for both the solutions or any other solution to handle this bug.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-04-25 18:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi all, I took a stab at a simpler solution that ensures transactional atomicity for the create_user call here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27507/1

Please let me know what you think of this.

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-04-25 18:59:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Jay, I'm reviewing your approach.  It will have a minor negative effect in that there will be some slight code duplication, but then it will allow a transaction take place entirely within the SQL backend.  That is probably an acceptable trade off.  It will also keep transactions alive across multiple calls from the Keystone server, which might have a performance impact, if only in a replicated Keystone deployment.  Get it working and we can move the reviews over there."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-04-25 19:15:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks Adam, I'm investigating why authorization seems to be failing in the devstack gate under my patch. Very odd (since creating a user shouldn't affect authorization, right?)

Anyway, will update the patch accordingly once I figure out what's going on."}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2013-04-26 20:14:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I like the looks of Jay's approach to isolating the driver access code into the drivers so that transactions can be applied on that level, I'd like to see a little more to see if that will end up in reasonable code for more of the calls.

That said, even if we do that we'll still want to get the sql transaction code in, and I think this is a good start.

Overall I don't like the handle_atomic_transaction decorator, for a few reasons:
1. I think we are overusing decorators a bit already in the project to do magic
2. If you're doing a decorator with params, better to do it as a callable class with an __init__, much clearer code
3. the "api_type" param makes things feel like a hack to me, I'd rather be passing the actual instance of, for example, identity_api.
4. Transactions are pretty much exactly what context managers were designed for, how abouts a "with transactify(self.identity_api)" or something like that instead of a decorator
5. It would be great if Jay's idea works cleanly and we can push this all down a level into the driver anyway
6. Naming is hard but that name is too long :p
7. The docstring needs reformatting ;)'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2013-04-26 20:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

fuck you, gerrit, keep my frickin newlines

I like the looks of Jay's approach to isolating the driver access code into the drivers so that transactions can be applied on that level, I'd like to see a little more to see if that will end up in reasonable code for more of the calls.

That said, even if we do that we'll still want to get the sql transaction code in, and I think this is a good start.

Overall I don't like the handle_atomic_transaction decorator, for a few reasons: 

  1. I think we are overusing decorators a bit already in the project to do magic 

  2. If you're doing a decorator with params, better to do it as a callable class with an __init__, much clearer code 

  3. the "api_type" param makes things feel like a hack to me, I'd rather be passing the actual instance of, for example, identity_api. 

  4. Transactions are pretty much exactly what context managers were designed for, how abouts a "with transactify(self.identity_api)" or something like that instead of a decorator 

  5. It would be great if Jay's idea works cleanly and we can push this all down a level into the driver anyway 
 
  6. Naming is hard but that name is too long :p 

  7. The docstring needs reformatting ;)'}, {'account_id': 6124, 'date': '2013-05-03 07:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-03 07:48:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/6/check/gate-keystone-pep8/4884 : SUCCESS in 00:01:15
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/25517/6/check/gate-keystone-docs/3258/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 00:01:57
- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/6/check/gate-keystone-python26/3778 : SUCCESS in 00:09:46

- http://logs.openstack.org/25517/6/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/2252 : FAILURE in 00:09:45 (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-05-03 13:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Rohan, this latest patch is much cleaner, IMO. While I still think that the appropriate solution is to have a single entry point in the driver, this solution certainly works across the different transaction-capable drivers (identity.sql, token.sql, etc), and is much cleaner than the original patch.'}, {'account_id': 6124, 'date': '2013-05-09 07:10:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Adam, Termie, Dolph, can you guys please review the latest patchset and provide feedback?'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-24 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-24 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Abandoned

commit_message:
Make create user api call atomic

* Adds transaction control support to make api calls atomic
* Make create user api atomic.

Fixes LP Bug #1130676

Change-Id: I9f236ec5815e17e8100fe64a953805e3c4dc6467

commit_message:
Do not give additional file descriptor to services

Some service does not close the inherited file descriptors.
A starter scripts should avoid using additional FDs,
 unless it is required by the started services.

The simple way to avoid unexpected FD inheritance situation,
 is not creating additional FDs.

This change tries to mimic the original behavior as possible.
* After the "Fin" the logging might be different in many configuration.
* Not VERBOSE without LOGFILE configurations will be more verbose.
* Will not use the spinner on non-tty output

Change-Id: Ibdd91c4c291fb35250eecc03c6ec53fbca24d8eb

To use this patch you need to have:

1) linux kernel >= 3.7
2) iproute2 >= 3.7
3) add following to linuxbridge_conf.ini
tenant_network_type=vxlan
network_vlan_ranges=physnet1:1000:2000
physical_interface_mappings = physnet1:eth0'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-24 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-05-24 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

Hi,
I have just been briefly over the code. First and foremost very nice additions.
There are two basic problems that need to be addressed:
1. The database is being updated - hence you need to add support for the database migrations
2. You are modifying the RPC data. This requires versioning.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-05-24 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I've just taken a quick look at this. If changing the linuxbridge RPC call signatures, please consider changing them to match those used by the openvswitch and hyperv plugins and agents exactly. This patch adds network_type to the linuxbridge RPC, so I'd suggest also renaming vlan_id to segmentation_id, and having linuxbridge use the flat network_type explicitly instead of a special vlan_tag value. This will avoid confusion, and help with the ml2 plugin, which is intended to support the linuxbridge, openvswitch, and hyperv agents (simultaneously). I'm not quite sure how to handle the RPC versioning for such a change though, unless we were to bump all three of them to use the same new RPC version number.

One other thought is that if we decide at the summit to move forward aggressively with ml2, we could make the linuxbridge agent changes for vxlan, avoid making these linuxbridge plugin changes, and just support vxlan with ml2 via an ml2 type_driver for vxlan. But I'm not suggesting delay on this overall patch if its ready before ml2."}, {'account_id': 6524, 'date': '2013-05-24 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Initial support for vxlan on linuxbridge.

blueprint vxlan-linuxbridge

Linux kernel starting from 3.7 offer native support for vxlan. This is
initial implementation of this feature in quantum for linuxbridge.

Change-Id: I7c6558c3fd890ca76d5dea02ddab005470aa787c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-02 19:07:50.000000000', 'message': 'Call format_message on InstanceTypeNotFound exception

Put the exception message from InstanceTypeNotFound into the
HTTPBadRequest rather than the exception itself.  Prevents a Circular
reference error during serialization later.

Bug 1175414

Change-Id: I4811e727311af670cd964a6d16ac5fce0fe3186e
(cherry picked from commit 051cf0d756d9a9e1d0a5ea1169fa97d89b7885bc)
'}]
commit_message:
Call format_message on InstanceTypeNotFound exception

Put the exception message from InstanceTypeNotFound into the
HTTPBadRequest rather than the exception itself.  Prevents a Circular
reference error during serialization later.

Bug 1175414

Change-Id: I4811e727311af670cd964a6d16ac5fce0fe3186e
(cherry picked from commit 051cf0d756d9a9e1d0a5ea1169fa97d89b7885bc)

commit_message:
Move OpenShift Origin related files to own directory.

This is consistent with top-level heat-templates directories
being targetted at different audiences.

This directory may also contain autoscaling templates, yaml variants
and diskimage-builder elements.

Change-Id: Id6f9084e57104f58c65bdf94c7d799e3773f7541

commit_message:
Disallow resize if image not available

If a resize is attempted on an instance that was started from an image
that has since been deleted, a resize will fail. This change makes error
reporting a bit cleaner.

This change is needed since in order to actually properly support
resize/migrate when the image is deleted - it is necessary for nova to keep
a copy of the image metadata and re-use it in case of migration/resize.

Fixes bug: 1160773
Fixes bug: 1177001

Change-Id: Ifaea71f79c97046a4cde094e3a5e676772fcceb4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 17:28:50.000000000', 'message': "Reset task_state when resetting vm_state to ACTIVE

A virt driver can raise InstanceFaultRollback to indicate that the
instance should be reset to ACTIVE.  However, the code that resets to
ACTIVE does not reset task_state to None.

This patch fixes that.  Technically, there's currently no bug here,
because the compute manager methods that matter here all have the
reverts_task_state() decorator to always reset task_state to None on
exceptions.  However, a bug would be introduced later if we remove
those decorators.

Change-Id: Ibcf8ae3473f601781d8aae80f88df3da54bbaac8
"}]
commit_message:
Reset task_state when resetting vm_state to ACTIVE

A virt driver can raise InstanceFaultRollback to indicate that the
instance should be reset to ACTIVE.  However, the code that resets to
ACTIVE does not reset task_state to None.

This patch fixes that.  Technically, there's currently no bug here,
because the compute manager methods that matter here all have the
reverts_task_state() decorator to always reset task_state to None on
exceptions.  However, a bug would be introduced later if we remove
those decorators.

Change-Id: Ibcf8ae3473f601781d8aae80f88df3da54bbaac8

commit_message:
Adds live migration support to cells API

Fixes bug 1153087

DocImpact: Cells now allows live migration within a cell,
but not between cells.

Change-Id: Ic8777c376883eaf6ff9cb4b379e0bacbfe5635b7

commit_message:
Show Heat links in a panel group on project dashboard

The group title is 'Orchestration' and currently the only panel
is 'Stacks'.

In the previous Thermal demo there was a separate dashboard called
'Heat'. I think a panel group is more appropriate, since Heat stacks
exist in the context of a project, just like Compute and Object Store.

Also, users will currently see 'Orchestration' as the title of this
feature, since Heat is project jargon.

Implements blueprint: heat-ui

Change-Id: I2ec26d26f5e54203903d8b6c11f9286afa3dff2c

commit_message:
Add Event methods to db api.

Start of adding the ability to store raw events in Ceilometer.
Query Filter mechanism is crude for now. Need to find a more expressive
grammar than this EventFilter thing.

Change-Id: I3c64e3858df756d93dd5bf3c6c9651be25cd2b55
Blueprint: add-event-table

subject: Adds duplicate iniset to lowercase 'ovs' group in quantum conf files

- http://logs.openstack.org/30214/2/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5425 : FAILURE in 10m 35s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-23 05:50:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't think this really helps except it makes devstack work again. What about existing deployments config files."}, {'account_id': 4726, 'date': '2013-05-23 06:48:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

devstack re-create config files from Quantum tree, so I think that existing deployment files are unrelated.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-05-23 07:24:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Aaron Rosen,
what do u mean by existing deployment file?
zhongyue said if all the reference code in quantum are modified to use lowercase group name, we can deal with the current capital case group name deployment file with oslo.cofig 1.20.
so what we need to do is to make sure all the group reference is using the lower case group name. In fact, why isn't oslo.conf tolerant with the conf.OVS.xx and conf.ovs.xxx at the same time. This way, we will have a buffer to move from capital group name into lower case one."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-23 07:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Aaron, gongysh

gongysh is right. once oslo.config v1.2.0a is used in Quantum, existing conf files using capital letter group names can be used. Thus the conf files are backwards compatible.

The compatibility issue which was considered at that time was conf file only, not code.
The reason was if we also normalized references to group names then 1) too much overhead is added when only quantum had to change the references to lowercase and 2) for minimum code change as possible
(These comments are my views and opinions do not represent those of other oslo cores.)

So I expect it will be a rough ride till we get Quantum to use oslo.config 1.2.0a but it has to be done sooner or later. Lets come up with a plan with minimum confusion.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 08:32:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I don't see what this "rough ride" you're referring to is

Quantum should/could have started using 1.2.0a1 with *zero* code changes

At that point, we could use config files with either uppercase or lowercase group names

Then we can start moving the code references, one-by-one, to lowercase by changing the group name passed to register_opt() from uppercase to lowercase

And all the time during this process, we could continue to use config files with either uppercase or lowercase group names'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-23 10:49:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

https://review.openstack.org/30250
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30094/

These two patches will fix the problem.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-24 02:21:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mark,

I admit I was a acting too early. Will communicate better with others next time. thanks.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 04:49:53.000000000', 'message': "Adds duplicate iniset to lowercase 'ovs' group in quantum conf files

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config 1.2.0 normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.

Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before we update oslo.config.

In the process of switching option group names to lowercase in Quantum,
we've confronted a problem which breaks gateing tests using devstack
because oslo.config 1.2.0 is not yet adapted but devstack inisets on
group name 'OVS'.

To resolve this problem this patch adds an duplicate iniset on option group
'ovs' for each iniset of options below group 'OVS'

Change-Id: Iebf71cecdf6f742ef7d0c526aa46dd78cb2b5213
"}, {'created': '2013-05-23 04:51:17.000000000', 'message': "Adds duplicate iniset to lowercase 'ovs' group in quantum conf files

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config 1.2.0 normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.

Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before Quantum updates oslo.config.

In the process of switching option group names to lowercase in Quantum,
we've confronted a problem which breaks gateing tests using devstack
because oslo.config 1.2.0 is not yet adapted but devstack inisets on
group name 'OVS'.

To resolve this problem this patch adds an duplicate iniset on option group
'ovs' for each iniset of options below group 'OVS'

Change-Id: Iebf71cecdf6f742ef7d0c526aa46dd78cb2b5213
"}]
commit_message:
Adds duplicate iniset to lowercase 'ovs' group in quantum conf files

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config 1.2.0 normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.

Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before Quantum updates oslo.config.

In the process of switching option group names to lowercase in Quantum,
we've confronted a problem which breaks gateing tests using devstack
because oslo.config 1.2.0 is not yet adapted but devstack inisets on
group name 'OVS'.

To resolve this problem this patch adds an duplicate iniset on option group
'ovs' for each iniset of options below group 'OVS'

Change-Id: Iebf71cecdf6f742ef7d0c526aa46dd78cb2b5213

commit_message:
Manually build dkms modules.

For some undiagnosed reason dkms modules were not being built during
image build time. Implement a simple loop to build and install them,
fixing bug 1182200.

Change-Id: Ib453b42e3b30b88d766535a2c1bc2f19bcb1d09c

Corrected Mistake to ssh to the newly created VM

it must come from the Network node not the Compute node

Experimenting with Oxygen and text width.

commit_message:
consistent i18n placeholders (flake8 H701, H702, H703)

- eliminates ambiguously defined keywords in i18n strings which may
  become incorrectly ordered in a corresponding translation.
- ensures formatting operations occur outside of i18n calls
- use bare multiline string concatenation instead of 'ab' + \n 'cd'
- eliminates an 'empty localization string' (passing a variable to i18n
  function)

Change-Id: I0d78b978cc730e5fb892b80dfacaaf6687cd80be

commit_message:
Fixed probetests

* Fixed issue with running probetests with the latest update
  of python-swiftclient that removed eventlet
* Fixed issue with replication server tests to not require hard
  coded paths

Change-Id: Ibbf727ae99c0f3893ae58e270e2f879a1f618e49

[{'created': '2013-05-23 12:13:46.000000000', 'message': "Remove -y option from package install

There are several places where packages get installed, some
used just 'apt-get/yum install', others added a '-y' option.
For consistency let us use the same way everywhere - Anne proposed
to remove the -y.

Change-Id: I131353b7d40f450d0663843b8715b7f891646227
"}]
commit_message:
Remove -y option from package install

There are several places where packages get installed, some
used just 'apt-get/yum install', others added a '-y' option.
For consistency let us use the same way everywhere - Anne proposed
to remove the -y.

Change-Id: I131353b7d40f450d0663843b8715b7f891646227

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-24 00:06:18.000000000', 'message': "Set correct mode for .ssh/authorized_keys files.

Per bug 1182648 we were not setting the mode and as a result couldn't
log in, defeating the purpose of having a local-config element :).

Change-Id: I4114b9536392f1517eac8f4bbe6f4b60ce1186a1
"}]
commit_message:
Set correct mode for .ssh/authorized_keys files.

Per bug 1182648 we were not setting the mode and as a result couldn't
log in, defeating the purpose of having a local-config element :).

Change-Id: I4114b9536392f1517eac8f4bbe6f4b60ce1186a1

"}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-01-17 09:12:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

My bad.
I should think of old-style arguments like --tenant_id.
I will reposet a new patchset to fix them.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-01-17 09:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-01-17 09:49:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

With user and tenant names having the potential of not being globally unique in domains with private name spaces (a new feature with the v3 Identity API), we need to consider how this kind of "by name" operation can work in that scenario.  Do we supply a domain name as well, or assume the domain the user was created in?  While none of this applies to a v2 API client (like the one you are updating), I don't think we want to add a new feature like this without understanding how it will work with v3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-17 10:02:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/19899/2/check/gate-python-keystoneclient-docs/495 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/19899/2/check/gate-devstack-vm-quantum/4123 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-01-17 10:08:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi henry-nash,
thank you for the comment.

If the specified name is not unique, glance command fails with
message "Multiple tenant matches found for 'test', use an ID to be more".
Is the above implementation not enough ?'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-01-17 16:54:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi ken'ichi

So the approach of getting a list of entities and then do a match on the name (and hence spotting that it is not unique) is conceptually good.  However, we are currently working through how v2 apis will respond in a multi-domain Grizzly environment.  I'd like us to resolve that (which is in progress right now) before we go ahead with this change.  Here are the blueprints, for reference:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18805/
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/default-domain

I just want to make that for any call that uses names, it fails because it spots there are duplicates, or is obvious which entity you are operating on"}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-01-18 06:14:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi henry-nash, thank you for the explanation.

OK, now I am waiting for your work related to multi-domain.
Could you consider this patch after it?

Thanks in advance.'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-01-18 14:50:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Absolutely.  In fact I don't think we need to wait for that to be implemented...just agreement on how v2/v3 api calls will be handled for name attributes like user and project.....thanks for being patient...."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-01-19 06:06:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I completely agree with henry, but there have been many attempts at a patch similar to this one in the past, and this is by far the best solution for v2.

Applying this to the delete methods is a little scary to me, because there's the possibility that you're deleting something based on a mutable value (you may not actually delete what you're think you're deleting).

Big +2 for applying this to the *-get operations, at the very least. Nice work!"}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2013-01-24 21:42:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm good with merging as soon as we've worked out how this will apply to V3 APIs"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-01-28 13:14:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Joe: (that's happening openstackclient)"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-05 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-05 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add name arguments to keystone command.

This patch adds name arguments to the following subcommands:
  * role-delete
  * role-get
  * service-delete
  * service-get
  * tenant-delete
  * tenant-get
  * tenant-update
  * user-delete
  * user-get
  * user-password-update
  * user-role-add
  * user-role-list
  * user-role-remove
  * user-update

Fixes bug 1100648

Change-Id: I73c08c0ba553a72ec57ff3a684a00be4ef1294a6

commit_message:
engine : move update_template_diff functions into Resource

Move the update_template_diff and update_template_diff_properties
functions into resource.Resource - since they now raise
resource.UpdateReplace we can avoid ever calling handle_update if
the resource update will result in replacement

Note a further cleanup will probably be to combine the two diff
functions into one recursive diff, which will further simplify this

Change-Id: I839f0c4448a2d869f35e0a4f19d17f31c5c6f9af

commit_message:
Instance resource remove unreachable/redundant Metadata update check

update_template_diff already throws resource.UpdateReplace if the
json_snippet contains changes other than to Metadata, so the else
here is unreachable and redundant

Change-Id: I9f0ad88d0b6fa65cafd5b2843a38913fa843a3ac

'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-05-20 19:22:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't think this is actually "cleaner". Just because it is less code does not make it easier to read.

It is not an exception that the resource requires replacement, it is a completely normal situation. Thus, I believe this to be an abuse of exceptions.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-20 20:38:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> It is not an exception that the resource requires replacement, it is a completely normal situation. Thus, I believe this to be an abuse of exceptions.

I disagree, we're calling handle_update(), and the resource *cannot* be updated, it must be destroyed and re-created with the new definition - IMHO this matches the definition of exception perfectly, in the context of the particular operation, and the scope of "Resource"/"Stack" abstractions, it is an error condition, since the resource cannot be updated.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-05-20 23:04:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It seems we sit on opposite sides fundamentally, and so I think we'll just have to agree to disagree. I think thats fine and I'm perfectly happy to accept it if others feel differently than me.

Just to make my position clear, here it is restated:

Replacement is a valid update pattern for many resources and properties. It is predictable to have a resource replaced that has had any of its fundamental properties changed, or if it is the kind of resource that simply cannot be updated.

Treating replacement as an exception frames it as an error and thus a special, unpredictable situation needing all of the help of non local return and back-tracing that an error needs.

It should not be considered an error to change the image id or instance type on a stateless instance resource and then update the template. A user will be fully expecting, as the cloudformation documentation states, and hopefully soon Heat's documentation will state, that it will be replaced. This doesn't need to be logged, investigated, or handled with special syntactic sugar."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-05-20 23:19:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So FWIW, using exceptions for flow control is Pythonic, *but* I think perhaps Clint's critique can be rephrased, which is to say - lets handle the situation where a replacement is required locally, rather than throwing through potentially many stack frames : contain the complexity, and make it easier to reason about in the higher levels of code.

What isn't Pythonic - so far at least - is conditional code based on return value.

e.g.

def foo():
   if cond:
      return 12
   return 34

def bar():
    v = foo()
    if v == 12:
       thing()
    elif v == 34:
       # error case
       otherthing()

is not common in Python...

Instead returning objects that can be acted on, or raising an exception to signal that no such object is available, or the operation failed, is the common pattern."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-21 07:52:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> lets handle the situation where a replacement is required locally, rather than throwing through potentially many stack frames : contain the complexity, and make it easier to reason about in the higher levels of code.

Define "locally"?  A resource.Resource object cannot replace itself, so the logic to do the replacement must live in parser.Stack

>What isn't Pythonic - so far at least - is conditional code based on return value.

Exactly - which is why I'm trying to remove this pattern, where we use a magic string returned from handle_update for the conditional blocks

>Instead returning objects that can be acted on, or raising an exception to signal that no such object is available, or the operation failed, is the common pattern.

Yep, which is why I'm trying to move to this, more pythonic pattern here (the original non-pythonic approach was my fault btw, I just realized it could be improved hence this patch, a follow-up to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29543/)

Perhaps some context would be helpful here:
- In https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29544/ Zane said "I really, really think "return self.UPDATE_REPLACE" should be "raise UpdateReplace" - I had already started this patch doing exactly that

- I'm in the process of adding additional resource states (suspend/resume/pause/stop/restart), and having a ever-expanding list of magic strings duplicated for every state and returned by the handle_foo() functions is going to result in a big mess.  The idea is that the resource will just raise exception.ResourceFailure if an error happens in any of the state-transition-handling handle_foo() functions, so we don't need to define OK/FAIL return values for every single state.  Given that we're doing that, it makes no sense (IMO) to maintain the old return-a-string pattern for update-replacement, which is really just a special type of ResourceFailure, in that the resource cannot be updated, so we've failed to complete handle_update()

https://github.com/hardys/heat/tree/WIP/stack-suspend-resume'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-21 11:26:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(6 inline comments)

I think I understand what Clint is trying to say - the idea that exceptions should be reserved only for truly "exceptional" cases is a fairly common design heuristic.

That's a useful heuristic, though I'm not sure it's the only one that applies. One purpose of exceptions is to provide out-of-band signalling of errors, to avoid the case that Robert mentions where we are returning a particular string amongst many possible strings in order to signal that a failure occurred (in C, the getc() function returning EOF is a vivid example of the problems that result from doing this.)

In this case the Stack is asking the Resource to update itself. If it cannot update itself then it must flag an error somehow, so that the Stack can replace it. Is this truly "exceptional" to warrant an exception? Arguably not, since it can be expected that in many cases the resource will not be able to update itself. It is, however, preferable to the alternatives IMO. Interrogating the resource beforehand to find out if an update is possible is not practical in this instance. And returning a magic value - or any value - seems inappropriate for a function that is designed to _do_ something, not to calculate or fetch some data.

I think with changes I have suggested inline, the value of this might be more obvious as well - utility routines can raise this exception without requiring the plugins to explicitly handle them. The current system requires plugins to do too much.

Finally, just as a practical matter, there is a good chance we may want to turn Resource.update() into a coroutine at some point, and coroutines cannot have return values (in Python 2).'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:29:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

First off, great discussion and I really appreciate everything you guys have to say, and that you are taking the time to consider what I have to say.

I will accept that exceptions can, and sometimes even should be used entirely for flow control.

However, I don't agree with the position that we can't interrogate all of the resources to see if they can be updated before trying. We already do it that way, we just, as Zane says, leave it up to the resources themselves, but unnecessarily.

I did a quick audit of all of the current handle_update methods. They boil down to two patterns:

* Just replace this resource
* Try to use self.update_template_diff, ortherwise replace

Only instance implements the pattern with any realistic variation, and I think it is a bug (since we only allow Metadata to be updated, but it checks again for metadata in the diff).

So, I think we can easily say that update_template_diff could very easily be called by Resource.update ahead of time.

If we did that, there is no need for an exception or return value anywhere. Resource plugin implementers can declare what is logically updatable with update_allowed_keys and update_allowed_properties. handle_update can just be handed the json snippet diff, or never be called.

With all due respect to the high quality of this work, I'd much rather see that kind of cleanup than this one."}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-05-22 23:56:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think I am with Clint on this one. I really don't like
coping this update code chunk around."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-23 11:25:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 11:29:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-05-23 12:11:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Changing my mind - growing on me, we can always tweak it later if it is *really* bugging us.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:09:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(2 inline comments)

I like it but I would be interested to hear Clint's take on this version before it gets merged."}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:59:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I like this for no other reason than it allows removal of obvious things. I also think the use of the UpdateReplace exception is at least a little more appropriate. I also just love patches that remove more code than they add. :)

I do think we can go further and move the template diffing out of the resources, but that sort of change deserves some thought and reasoning outside this cleanup.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:59:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

commit_message:
engine : replace UPDATE_REPLACE with ResourceReplace exception

Replace the handle_update returned value with a new ResourceReplace
exception, which allows the replacement logic in resource.py and
parser.py to be cleaner

Change-Id: If652d031e8baeb8f4c6015e5ed2d0e5bb25f0fc6

At least consider aliasing the config value in tests/api/instances.py. In other tests/api files, it may not be so important as it's only evaluated once or twice, but I count more than a dozen uses of the comparison in instances.py alone.

And I may be misunderstanding the changes, but I don't see many tests that put 'Root' and 'Ephemeral' through their paces. Most of the additions just seem to be shutting tests off if 'Volume' isn't today's secret word."}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-23 23:26:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-23 23:26:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Ed,

The reason that you see a lot of check for 'Volume' is due to the way rd-client creates instances. When 'Volume' is enabled, a param 'size' must be passed to the client.

There are also tests that are turned off which includes volume-quota and volume-resize. Ephemeral and Root are not applicable for quota or resize.

I have also ran the test in Root and Ephemeral and they passed. Perhaps we should run the int-tests three times. One with each of the config storage_device"}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-23 23:26:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Ed,

Not sure if it would be that beneficial to have use what you suggested:
VOLUME_SUPPORT = CONFIG.storage_device == 'Volume'

The reason is because now we have 3 possible values: Volume, Ephemeral and Root partition. So in a way,VOLUME_SUPPORT == false could mean either Ephemeral or Root.

We are trying to convert a 3-value variable to a boolean.

If it's the fact that we are pulling this value from the config a lot that bothers you, we could create a new variable in a base class and have it query the config file once. IE STORAGE_DEVICE = CONFIG.storage_device.

Let me know what you think."}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-23 23:26:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (6 inline comments)

'}, {'created': '2013-05-23 23:26:24.000000000', 'message': 'Ephemeral volume support

This feature enables reddwarf to create instance and run mysql on ephemeral disk.
To enable this feature, use the config "storage_device". Set this variable to 'Volume', 'Ephemeral' or 'Root'.

The config reddwarf_volume_support has been replaced with storage_device.
If this value is set to 'Volume', RD will storage mysql data on cinder volumes.
If it is set to 'Root', it will storage mysql data on the root partition.

fixes LP bug# 1175719
BP: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/reddwarf/+spec/ephemeral-storage-volume

Change-Id: I869297e7da288ac42b359c8cdb731e8b7281d51b

The config reddwarf_volume_support has been replaced with storage_device.
If this value is set to 'Volume', RD will storage mysql data on cinder volumes.

fixes LP bug# 1175719

commit_message:
Ephemeral volume support

This feature enables reddwarf to create instance and run mysql on ephemeral disk.
To enable this feature, set the flag "reddwarf_volume_support to False and specify the device_path and mount_point variables.

Also added int tests for ephemeral support

fixes LP bug# 1175719
BP: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/reddwarf/+spec/ephemeral-storage-volume

Change-Id: I869297e7da288ac42b359c8cdb731e8b7281d51b

[{'created': '2013-05-23 23:24:04.000000000', 'message': "Fix permission errors with nova-kvm.

Per bug 1183274 qemu needs read permission on the instance files and
backing files or else it cannot open (and then chown/chmod) them.

At the same time I removed a little cruft that had built up - we don't
use /var/run/nova/instances at all.

Change-Id: Idf77a65269c0e238097a4d2cb6932c30e0e031c5
"}]
commit_message:
Fix permission errors with nova-kvm.

Per bug 1183274 qemu needs read permission on the instance files and
backing files or else it cannot open (and then chown/chmod) them.

At the same time I removed a little cruft that had built up - we don't
use /var/run/nova/instances at all.

Change-Id: Idf77a65269c0e238097a4d2cb6932c30e0e031c5

commit_message:
Make baremetal directory setup baremetal specific.

Per 1183532 we don't need the tftp directory touched or altered on
non-baremetal compute nodes.

Change-Id: I6e9912fa08e0a57fce4d24222a9691aeb1cb2fc2

Hey,
As about question:
"Why does test_utils appears like deleted and added? It would be better to just rename that file."

Seems this is how git displays patches.
I've done all my best (in 3 separate commits I try to receive R near this test, so I reset such file to the master version, commit this, than add new test to it - commit this and finally execute command git mv from glance/tests/unit/test_utils.py to glance/tests/unit/common/test_utils.py and commit, but as result we still see this file as deleted and added into the new place ) :(
~/repos/glance$ git commit --am
[bug/1152183 493fda3] Improve unit tests for glance.common package
 4 files changed, 157 insertions(+)
 create mode 100644 glance/tests/unit/common/__init__.py
 rename glance/tests/unit/{ => common}/test_clients.py (97%)
 rename glance/tests/unit/{ => common}/test_config.py (96%)
 rename glance/tests/unit/{ => common}/test_utils.py (57%)
 rename glance/tests/unit/{ => common}/test_wsgi.py (80%)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-05 12:42:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-04-05 20:11:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> Flavio Percoco Premoli
> Why does test_utils appears like deleted and added? It would be better to just rename that file.

Linus Torvalds says:

git really doesn't even care about the whole "rename detection" internally, and any commits you have done with renames are totally independent of the heuristics we then use to show the renames.

(http://marc.info/?l=git&m=119638337122721&w=2)

So. it's Gerrit's fault (it cannot detect the rename), but not Tatyana's.'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-04-05 20:11:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-04-08 08:02:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

> So. it's Gerrit's fault (it cannot detect the rename), but not Tatyana's.

mmhh, weird thing is that downloading the patch shows the file as renamed. My concern is that delete -> create destroys file's history.

It definitely seems like gerrit's fault. Thanks for pointing that out!"}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-04-10 16:48:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Improve unit tests for glance.common package

Add tests for next modules:
* glance.common.wsgi
* glance.common.utils
* glance.common.client
* glance.common.config

Fixes: bug #1152183
Change-Id: Iedbdfb6af411170da10d078e48f5098f8d1c668b

commit_message:
Revert "Reference OVS OptGoup names in lowercase"

This reverts commit b8b2c4ebec7f8687215b5fd17a6f0fde84aee043.

This patch breaks current deployments that use uppercase OVS.

Change-Id: I6b8a83e2865fd2eb4dc3e322532517620132f94d

This will be necessary as we start to introduce objects with
real dicts in system_metadata. These are the common spots that
need to be ready ahead of time. The rest are at the actual use
sites and can/will be replaced when individual uses are
converted to objects.

Related to bp/unified-internal-objects

commit_message:
Make a few places tolerant of sys_meta being a dict

This will be necessary as we start to introduce objects with
real dicts in system_metadata. These are the common spots that
need to be ready ahead of time. The rest are at the actual use
sites and can/will be replaced when individual uses are
converted to objects.

Related to bp/unified-internal-objects

Change-Id: I8314e0d52ec2ae800765f60ce58ce9b309d7d513

commit_message:
Allow for memcache_servers override attributes

Right now the memcache_servers function is used throughout a number of
the cookbooks. For those who have not defined a memcache role, this
can be problematic as it uses search. This would also be problematic
for those wanting to use chef-solo without search and/or test-kitchen.

So, just provide an override attribute to override search for
memcache_servers.

New test added to support this and all tests pass.

Change-Id: Iff655ff066d8aa933eedb67ac17611288b57a2f0

The ext4 resize fix was faulty - fix it.

Fix bug 1183251 by replacing an erroneous reference to OPTS with
MKFS_OPTS.

commit_message:
Enumerate ignored flake8 H* rules

We were previously ignoring all H* rules; this patch specifically
identifies them so that we can eliminate them one by one, without
introducing regressions along the way.

Change-Id: I3f18f8f9aec8657697c711f5fbb23ec687ce28f0

commit_message:
Use sql instead of kvs for EC2 credential storage.

Heat uses ec2 credentials to facilitate its CloudFormation compatible
API's.

Fixes bug #1183442

Change-Id: I50acbd32b0af6be34a46d9923d15625604191e89

As zyluo wrote, we need to replace option group to lowercase before updating oslo.config to 1.2.0."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

Thanks for the clarification. I was confused.
I think I understand the behavior now and confirm we can upgrade oslo.config 1.2.0a1 safely.

- We can access cfg.<group> with a group name passed in register_opts. It is case sensitive.
- When reading the config file(s), group names are compared with lowercase names.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

Wait for I0344e39222b3aecad5e30f820014f4d9f672e90c'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

See also http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/009448.html'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This is incorrect

In I74c2a35aea7a52f9586eb598fe52d2cecb1851ef we did:

 -CONF.register_opts(_quota_opts, 'QUOTAS')
 +CONF.register_opts(_quota_opts, 'quotas')

*this* is what caused us to have to change from CONF.QUOTAS to CONF.quotas in the code

Take these lines of code as another example:

  CONF.register_opts(security_group_opts, 'SECURITYGROUP')

  firewall_driver = CONF.SECURITYGROUP.firewall_driver

This code will continue to work just fine after the upgrade to 1.2.0a1

We take oslo.config API compatibility very seriously with oslo.config - there is no incompatible API changes here

For each individual group, to make the move from referencing the group as upper case to lower case in your code base, you have to opt-in by registering that group using the lowercase name"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok, I've figured out the problem with the nvpopts test - working on fixing it"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok, it turns out we broke the API of MultiConfigParser - see I0344e39222b3aecad5e30f820014f4d9f672e90c for fix

I actually didn't realize anyone outside of oslo.config was using MultiConfigParser ... but now we know :)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

- http://logs.openstack.org/30094/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/24880 : SUCCESS in 20m 21s
'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Really sorry again for not being clear about this.

Quantum cannot use oslo.config 1.2.0 until all option group references switch to lowercase.

This is because the group name normalization only happens when conf files are read, not when referenced in code.

For example, if Quantum uses oslo.config 1.2.0 then all options below group [OVS] has to be referenced as cfg.CONF.ovs.xxx, not cfg.CONF.OVS.xxx.

How I propose to land oslo.config 1.2.0 is to first replace all capital letter group names in Quantum to lowercase while simultaneously adding duplicate inisets to Devstack in lowercase group name if the option group that is being replaced is used in Devstack.

After all capital group names are replaced then we can have Quantum use oslo.config 1.2.0 and remove the duplicate inisets in devstack.

please see http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/009433.html'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Guess I was wrong again :)
Thanks for correcting this.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Require oslo.config 1.2.0a2

Fixes bug #1182662

Commit 362bd7f switched us from using 'QUOTA' as a config file section
name to using 'quota'.

This broke backwards compatibility support for 'QUOTA' because the
version of oslo.config that has that compat support had not yet been
released. The gory details are summarized here:

  http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/009448.html

Change-Id: I7826087147e0713edaaea85a72283998295e2281
